loans.name: Edwin

texts.es:
Edwin tiene 49 años, vive con su pareja, quien es profesora, tienen 2 hijos que aun están estudiando. Él se dedica al transporte de pasajeros, hace 6 años empezó a trabajar como chofer y ahora es propietario de un motocarro (desde hace 2 años) con el que recorre las calles de su ciudad en busca de personas para trasladar de un lugar a otro. Pero esta no es la única actividad que realiza, pues también es mecánico de motos, oficio que aprendió de su padre y cuenta con un pequeño taller en su casa y son sus propios compañeros de trabajo (motocarristas), quienes lo buscan para reparar sus motos. Esta labor la realiza desde hace 19 años y le va muy bien, pues  Edwin viene luchando desde muy joven para mejorar su calidad de vida.
Este es su 4to crédito con MFP, él es parte de un banco comunal y lo que más le gusta de su grupo es que sus compañeros trabajan responsablemente y son solidarios entre sí. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará un motor nuevo para su motocarro, pues el que tiene actualmente está en mal estado, también adquirirá herramientas y materiales para su taller mecánico.

loans.use: Reparación de su motocarro

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel S., a technician at his own electronic shop, has many customers who rely on him to repair their old damaged televisions, air conditioners, and home appliances. The father of a one-year-old child, he hopes one day to have a bigger shop. He is just looking for an opportunity to get started expanding his business.

Joel now needs a loan of Php 10,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy materials and tools for his shop. Hopefully this loan will help him improve his services to attract more customers in the future.

loans.use: To buy materials for his electronics shop

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny is a very hard working individual. In the morning, she sells vegetables in her village from 8:00-11:00 and in the afternoon she sells snacks such as bananacue or turon (fried banana coated with sugar) and fresh lumpia (like a spring roll, with fried vegetables with sauce). She has been in this business for three years and this is her routine everyday to help her family earn a living. Her husband drives a tricycle owned by their neighbor and they also need to pay a daily fee for using the tricycle. Jenny's business plays a large role in providing the daily needs of their family especially the children.

However, their income is not enough to meet the growing needs of their family, therefore, Jenny is doing her best to succeed in her business. To make this possible, she would like a loan of PHP 4,000 from Kiva lenders. With additional capital, she can improve her business and make it more profitable. This will allow her to continue to support the education of her children as she really wants them to finish their studies.

Jenny has four children and three of them are already studying. The eldest is Baby Jane who is now 12 years-old. Jayson is 9 years-old, R-Jay, 7 years-old and their youngest is Jerald, 5 years-old.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Emerita

texts.es:
Emerita tiene 62 años, vive junto a su esposo y con uno de sus 4 hijos que es soltero. Hace 38 años se viene dedicando a la venta de bebidas y postres (gaseosas, cervezas, chupetes y gelatinas), negocio que atiende en su propia casa y que se ve favorecido por encontrarse ubicado muy cerca a un parque donde acuden muchas personas que debido al intenso calor de la región siempre requieren de sus bebidas heladas. Asimismo, debido a su deseo de mantenerse activa, por las noches vende tamales y humitas (platillos hechos a base de maíz y maní) en la puerta de su casa. A Emerita le gusta su trabajo porque conoce a muchas personas que se convierten en sus clientes y mantiene amenas conversaciones.
Este es su 9no préstamo con MFP, ella es parte de su banco comunal y lo que le gusta de su grupo es que entre todos se muestran mucha confianza y son muy unidos. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará sillas y mesas, así como gran cantidad de bebidas para seguir activa en este negocio que tanto le gusta.

loans.use: Incremento de mercadería y muebles para su negocio

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa S. is a rice grower from trento Agusan del Sur. she has two children. Her eldest is just 8 years old. The income that she makes from her farm has helped her family buy food, clothes and other basic needs.She would like to request a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to pay the owner of the equipment that she used during land preparation and buy farming necessities.

She started in CEVI since 2008 and she said that CEVI is helping her a lot improve her harvest. receiving another loan from CEVI will also help her gaian manage well their rice field.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma D. is a rice farmer. She has 5 children, 27 years old the ledest who are all her insporation to pursue her livelihood to buy food, clothes and basic needs in their family. In 1979, she was married to Julio, a farmer. From then on, she learned about farming, about tilling the wet foeld and harvesting the grains.

Now, she would like to apply a loan of Php 9,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. Receiving this loan is truly worthwhile because this definitely will go far in renting the equipment she borrowed during land preparation. 

Someday, she said that she likes to buy more farms. So that she will have more harvest to offer to her customers and earn bigger income for the education of her children.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Ma. Jesusa

texts.en:
Ma. Jesusa hails from the beautiful town of Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is 28-year-old mother to two daughters. She is happily married to Ricky who is 32 years old.
Even her young age, she dreams of giving descent life to her family specially to her children. She needs to start a business that could bring her good income. In 2008, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines with hopes of having access to capital to start a business. When she recieved her previos loans, she invested those in the resale business. Now she is engaged in the resale business for more than a year already and she wants to invest more on it.
Now on her third loan, she is requesting a loan of 15,000 pesos as additional capital for her business. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for 3 sacks of rice, 3 sacks sugar, 5 gallons of cooking oil, and also to pay for transportation expenses. She will resale the goods in thier village. People will just come to her store and will by thier needs.
She is optimistic that her business will grow with the access to capital provided by ASHI and with the trust of KIVA. She dreams of sending her children to school until college and also to build a house of her own on her own lot.

loans.use: To pay for 3 sacks of rice, 3 sacks sugar, 5 gallons of cooking oil, and also to pay for transportation expanses.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is a hog raiser for three years and still hoping for business expansion.  She wanted to purchase additional piglets to raise for additional income.  Aside from raising hogs, Flora is also engaged in the direct selling business of AVON, Natasha and MSE products which she sells and delivers to her friends and customers in their village. 

Flora is requesting to avail a loan amounting to PHP4, 000 that she can use to improve her two businesses.  She hopes that she will be able to avail the loan for the growth of her business towards progressive living. Flora also aims that all her children will someday finish their studies. 

She have two children and her youngest is in high school level.  Her eldest stopped from her college education since she had the chance to go to abroad and work as an Overseas Filipino Worker or OFW in the Middle East. Flora really hopes for the good future of all her children with the help of her business.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Mrs. Srei Kung Village Bank Loan Group

texts.en:
This village bank group is made up of 15 people who all live in Samraong village in Kandal province. The group members will use their loans for different purposes. Mrs. Srei K. is the village bank president selected by the members. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. She faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to buy farming supplies. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to enable her to buy farming supplies for her plantation. Her husband, Mr. Kuoy Lyhuor, is a motorbike taxi driver. The couple has four children, one of whom is a construction worker, two of whom are enrolled in the local school, and one of whom is too young to work or study.

Five members in this group have end-of-term (EoT) loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Those with EoT loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product because they are most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. These loans allow the borrower to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies

loans.name: Marylou

texts.en:
Marylou E. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 19 years-old and single. Marylou owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Marylou is just starting this business.

In 2009, Marylou joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marylou is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product range

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia is 59 years old and already a widow. She is the mother of five children and she is very proud that, through her sacrifices, she was able to send them to school and they were able to graduate from college. She is glad that they are very responsible and hard working. They also assists her in managing her general store business in their community in Zamora Street, Tuguegarao City. Leticia is doing also her best to improve her business to earn a higher income.

Leticia is very thankful for the success of her children and her general store business. She believes that this is the fruit of her sacrifices and the answer to her prayer. She wants further improvement of her business so she will not be too dependent on her children when they all have their own families. With this, she would like to obtain a loan of PHP 25,000 as additional capital that she can use for her store’s continuous development.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en:
Mary Grace is the 32-year-old mother to two daughters. She is happily married to Jose Rio who is 35 years old and a jeepney (small bus) driver. She lives in the beautiful town of Binangonan, Rizal Province, in the Philippines.

Mary Grace is full of determination to get out from the spiral of poverty. In 2008, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, with hopes of having access to capital. Prior to her membership with ASHI, she was already engaged in her general store business but her project was dying for lack of rolling capital. Her previous loans were carefully invested in her general store as rolling capital.

Mary Grace’s business runs smoothly since her neighbors became her regular customers. Now on her third loan, she proposes a loan of 15,000 pesos as additional capital for her general store. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for four sacks of rice, two sacks of sugar, cigarettes, soft drinks and other groceries for the store and also to pay for transportation expenses.

Mary Grace aspires to sending her children to school until they finish college and find jobs. She also dreams of expanding her business and improving it into a mini-mart someday.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz is the kind of person who prefers to be busy and she works tirelessly, for this makes her feel contented. She is already 54 years old and married. She lives in the village of Arcon, Tumauini, Isabela with her husband and three children.

Beatriz manages her own general store and food vending business. She sells cooked viands (tasty dishes) and she also sells fruit for additional income. Aside from this, Beatriz also travels to Dagupan City (approximately five hours from Ilagan, Isabela) twice a month in order to purchase fresh milk, fish, and other products like “bagoong” (shrimp paste) to retail in her village. This business gives her a net income of PHP 6,000 a month. She uses her income as rolling capital for the maintenance of her business.

At present, Beatriz would like her business to become more progressive. To attain this, she is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 from Kiva lenders. She hopes that her loan will be granted so that her business will grow, allowing her to meet the needs of her family.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Pom

texts.en:
N., 46 years old, is a married woman and a mother. To earn a living, N. buys black gelatin (a type of dessert) in bulk on credit from her wholesale supplier and then retails it in the local busy market.

N. is marred to Kheam, 47, a farmer, who also works with her in the business. She is blessed with six children, two of whom are married and live independently, while the others are teenagers. Two of her children sell dessert to earn a living and provide their income to better meet their family’s living expenses.

N. would like a loan to increase her business capital in order to gain more customers and income. She proposes to use some of the loan for her husband’s farm.

loans.use: To increase her business capital and to improve her husband's farm

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en:
Anthony N. is a farmer from Banga, South Cotabato. He has two children with his wife, Veronica N.. His family manages a 1-hectare (2.5-acre) rice field.

Anthony is grateful for the financial services he obtained when he became a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI). He said that ever since CEVI became his business partner, he hasn’t experienced many problems and he has been able to save because of the low interest rate.

Anthony applied for a loan of Php 12,000 that he will use to finance his farm. The loan will surely help Anthony and his family in improving their farm.

loans.use: To use as additional business capital

loans.name: Nashla Jean

texts.en: Nashla Jean N. is from the village of Sagay , Camiguin Province. She is 20 years old, is married, and has one infant child. Nashla Jean owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Nashla Jean joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en: Nenita L. lives with her husband, Wyler, in a middle-class home in Dasmarinas, Cavite. She is 56 years old. Nenita has been managing her general store since 2001. She revolves her profits as additional capital to buy more stock for her store. She now makes more than P16,000 net income per month. She uses much of her savings to invest in home furnishings. It has always been Nenita’s desire to share God’s word and to be of service to her neighbors. Since becoming a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2007, this desire was fulfilled. Now on her 6th loan with the cooperative, Nenita is applying for a loan of P15,000. She wants to add selling soft drinks and will buy more items to sell at her store. She dreams of converting her general store to a big grocery outlet someday. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy additional items to sell like softdrinks

loans.name: Obdulla

texts.en: Obdulla S. is from the village of Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 55 years old, is married, and has one adult child. Obdulla owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling umbrellas and shoe products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Obdulla joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Obdulla is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 4th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena is 51 years old and she is married to Gil, a driver in the Municipal Hall of Tumauini, Isabela located near their village in Arcon.  They are blessed with seven, three are already married, two are working and two are presently studying. Magdalena hopes to give her children a good future by working hard in her general store business. 

Magdalena is managing her store for many years.  Aside from her store, she also makes curtains, dresses and accepts clothing  repairs in their neighborhood.  At present, she would like to borrow a an additional business capital for her store and sewing business and she also believes that through this, she can also pursue her plan of so she can pursue her Magdalena is planning to have additional business capital which will be of big help to her business and soon will enable her to pursue her plan of selling cooked viands for extra income. She is hoping to avail a loan of PHP5, 000 from KIVa lenders.  This will be of great help in providing the needs not only for her business but also for her family.  She hopes that her request will be granted.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Lalaine

texts.en:
Lalaine manages a general store business in front of her house. Aside from this, she also rents a stall in their school where she put up a small canteen and sells snacks during school days in order to have an additional source of income. From 7:00-10:30 in the the morning she sells snacks in the school and resumes again at 12:00-2:30 in the afternoon. After selling snacks, this is the time when she opens her store at home.
 
Lalaine would like to obtain a loan of PHP 5,000 to be used as additional business capital for her store and school canteen business. She is hoping that, through her business and with the help of her husband, who operates a passenger tricycle, they will be able to provide for the educational needs of their children and enable them to finish their college education.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is a fish vendor in their semi-urban village Linao East, Tuguegarao City. She is now in need of business capital and with this she would like to avail a loan of PHP5, 000 that she can use for the improvement and growth of her business.  She usually purchase fish in wholesale price then sells them in retail price in their vilalge.  She dreams of having a bigger house someday and support the needs of her children.  She believes that through her business, nothing is impossible. 

Marilyn is already 40 years old and a mother to two children.  Their eldest is 17 years old while her youngest is 14 years old. Her children are attending school, one in college and one in high school. Marilyn hopes that she can afford to send them to school until they finish their college education for them to achieve their dreams in life.

loans.use: additional business capital

loans.name: Palwasha Group

texts.en:
Palwasha is the group leader of the four-member Palwasha group. Each group member wants a loan to improve and expand their business, and together they are requesting a group loan of 40,000 AFN.

Palwasha wants to take a loan for her tailoring business.
Sorya wants to take a loan for her husband’s taxi business.
Layla wants to take a loan for her husband's metal shop business.
Bibi Gull wants to take a loan for her husband’s clothes shop.

The group is pleased that such loans are available in Afghanistan and around the world.

loans.use: To expand and improve her tailoring business

loans.name: Jecelyn

texts.en: Jecelyn R. is from the village of Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 41 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Jecelyn owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling seafood products including fish and shrimp and fruit like pineapple in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Jecelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Jecelyn is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe Q. is from the village of Alga, Camiguin Province. She is 55 years old. Fe is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Fe makes and sells food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Fe has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2008, Fe joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fe has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Fe is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Fe from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia is 32 years old.  She an d her family are living in the village of Arcon, Tumauini, Isabela. She is married to Elmer, a tricycle driver and they have three children: Erwin,12 years old, elementary student; Emerson, 11 years old , also in elementary level and Erick Jay, 3 years old. Leticia is working hard so she can able to help her husband in providing the needs of their family especially to meet the needs of their children.  
 
Leticia is engaged in the vending business.  She sells fish, food snacks and vegetables in their village. She also sells different items such as fruits whenever she has extra capital to use. She sells her products in three neighboring villages and she is able to earn a daily net income of PHP500.00.  Fish vending is her first business until she was able to expand into vegetables, fruits and snacks. 

She hopes to further improve it and hoping to have her own stall in their village. She would like to borrow a loan of PHP4, 000 from KIVA lenders that she can use in the business.  Leticia dreams of having her own general store in the future for bigger income.  She hopes to attain all her dreams by starting to save some of her profits from her existing business and with the help of lenders. She is praying that God may help her reach her dreams.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Rogel

texts.en:
Rogel R. is from the village of Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 49 years old. Rogel is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Rogel owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector, running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily-use products in the local community. Rogel has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2008, Rogel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rogel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rogel is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Rogel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase commodities in bulk for her business

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina B. lives in a populous village in Malaria, Caloocan City near the market.  She is 37 years old.  Her husband June, 39, manages his own car detailing shop just beside their house.  They have six little children.

Gina started her business more than ten years ago distributing low-cost diaper overruns from factories to small stores in her community.  A few years of successful selling gave her enough courage to establish her general store in front of their house beside her husband’s workshop.  She still sells diapers in bulk and retail.  She now makes P25,000 a month.

She became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006 after attending a series of pre-membership seminars.  Gina is now in need of a new loan of P12,000 for the expansion of her general store.



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To expand her store.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther P. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 24 years old. Esther is married and has one young child. To make a living, Esther runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in her local community. Esther has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Esther joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Esther is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Esther from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
This is Elizabeth T., 59 years old, from Tala, Caloocan City.  Her husband Nestor, 58, works for a construction firm.  They have seven children.

Elizabeth owns a general store located at their house.  She also maintains computer game consoles which she rents out.  She has been in business for fifteen years.  She is earning close to P15,000 a month but a little less during rainy season.

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006 and has since been enjoying the many benefits it provides to its members.  Elizabeth has just finished repaying her previous loan with CCT and has applied for a new loan of P20,000.  She needs the money to purchase more stock for her store.  

She is also planning to start a computer shop in her community.      

      

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her store

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy T. lives in Zabarte Road, Caloocan City.  She is 25 years old.  She owns and manages a general store which she inherited from her parents when she got married.

Joy grew up with her general store, which is why this business is very dear to her.  From her profits, she was able to set up a small computer shop which proved to be another strong source of income for her family.  She earns at least P13,000 a month from the combined operations of the general store and the computer shop.

The start of 2009 was a real blessing for Joy.  She became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in the first week of January.  She was impressed at how her neighbors are progressing in their businesses so she gave it a try and was convinced of the many good things her neighbors have been telling her about the cooperative.  

Joy has applied for a new loan in the amount of P9,000 to purchase computer peripherals.  She is now religiously saving for the future of her children and so she can also open another branch for her computer shop.

      

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase computer peripherals

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Hem R. is 37-year-old married and mother. She lives in her own family house with other family members. To earn a living, Hem R. and her husband and her teenage sons depend on breaking stone from mountains to sell and have been started in this sector since 1991 to present. Usually, this family gets up in the morning to go to where they break stone and sell their peace of stone here to people who own their car for transporting. Hem R. has been facing difficulty with her living condition for along time due to her house is cracking down frequently. She is therefore looking for a US$500 loan from HKL. She will be used the haft of this loan to buy 30 peaces of zinc to cover her old house and the rest to purchase more equipments for breaking stone block. Hem R. and her husband and her son appear in the picture at their field work.

loans.use: To buy 30 peaces of zinc to cover her old house and the rest to purchase more equipments for breaking stone block

loans.name: Rubelyn

texts.en:
Rubelyn P. is from the village of Mambajao, in Camiguin Province. She is 29 years old. Rubelyn is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Rubelyn sells fruits and vegetables in the local community. Rubelyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rubelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rubelyn is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the first loan she has taken out from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Paz

texts.en:
Paz B. is already 61 years-old yet she seems to be untiring. She lives with her husband, Enrico, 60, a fellow vendor, in Caloocan City. Their only child is now married.

Paz has been selling fresh hog meat for fifteen years. She gets her supply from butchers who have been family friends over the years. She earns a net monthly income of P 10,000.00. From her profits which she religiously saved, she was able to have their house renovated. Her business has also grown bigger than ever from the profits which she has added to her capital in order to keep her business growing and going.

Paz became a member of Kiva partner the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006 and has since been testifying to the many good benefits her membership has brought to her business and personal life. On her 10th loan cycle, she seeks a loan in the amount of P16,000.00 as additional capital for further business expansion.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To provide additional capital for meat selling business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk

loans.name: Moeun

texts.en: The picture shows Mr. S. and his wife.  They work breaking stone. S. was born in 1966 and married in 1991. He currently helps meet his family’s living expenses by selling stone that he carves with his wife. He has been working in this field for more then ten years and is typically earning an average of US $10 each day. S. has two teenage children who go to study or work with him in carving stone. S. said that it is hard to get to the field to work because he does not have his own vehicle. Therefore, he has decided to seek a loan to purchase a motorbike which he and his family will use to ride to work or elsewhere. With the remainder of the loan he will buy more carving tools for his business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita is a native of Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is 43 years old and married to Benjamin who is 48 and her partner in her business. She has four children to take good care of. The eldest daughter is 21 years old and a college graduate while the youngest is six years old and an elementary school pupil.

As a mother, Juanita’s dreams are always for her children and family. She wants to bring her children into a decent life. In 2008, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines. She hoped to have access to capital for the continuation of her dying business. Her previous loans were carefully utilized as additional and rolling capital for her fish cage. A fish cage is used as a venue for fingerlings to be cultured until ready for harvest.

Now on her 3rd loan, Juanita proposes a loan of 15,000 pesos as additional capital for her fish-cage business. Specifically, the amount will be used to pay for three rolls of assorted fish nets, a hundred pieces on bamboo, wires and other tying materials and also for labor expenses.

Juanita is hopeful that her business will grow and that someday she will have more fish cages. She also dreams of sending all her children to school until college and that they find jobs. One of her aspirations is to be able to build a house that is durable and spacious.

loans.use: To pay for supplies and labor for her fish cage

loans.name: Fred's Group

texts.en:
S. Fred is a hardworking and determined businessman. He has been involved in the sale of metal crafts and shutters from Lugolole town for twelve years and he is happy that it enables him earn 40,000/= in profit. He buys metal scraps from which he makes the metal crafts and his goal is to become a big supplier of the metal materials for his children’s better future.

Fred is a married man with six children aged 28 to 2 years and he also cares for an orphan.

This is Fred’s second loan with Pearl Microfinance and he hopes to buy more metal materials to help in his business since this brings in more capital and more profits.

The man standing in the photo is Richard, the Credit officer in charge of the group.

loans.use: To buy more metal materials to increase his stock

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina O. is a 57-year-old mother of six. All of her children are now grown. She lives with her husband Leonisio in a small house in Bagong Silang, Caloocan City.

Five years ago Josefina built a general store off of their home. An offshoot of her retail business is her sale of cosmetics and apparel through popular direct sales programs such as Personal Collection, Avon, Sarah Lee, etc. Josefina also cooks and sells a popular streetside snack among Filipinos called banana-cue, a caramelized banana on a thin bamboo skewer. She earns at least 9000 PHP a month from these combined business activities.

She has been with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) credit cooperative for a year now. Now on her third loan cycle, she is requesting a 8000 PHP loan with the cooperative to purchase more cosmetics for her clients. She will also use a portion of the loan to buy bananas in bulk. Josefina has saved much of her earnings and is looking forward to having their house renovated soon.

About CCT:

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical missionary work in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy wholesale cosmetics and bananas

loans.name: Melina

texts.en:
Melina B. is a woman of faith, determined to rise above poverty. She is 45 years old and married to Romeo, a fisherman. They have three children, two sons and a daughter. The eldest son is fifteen years old and a high school student while the youngest is eleven and an elementary pupil. For almost twelve years Melina has been fishing using a fish cage. But there are times when she falls short of capital, which negatively affects her business.

In 2008 she decided to join ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in the hope that she could access capital through its loan program. Her previous two loans were carefully utilized on her fish cage business. With the support of her husband, Melina’s business brings in enough income to sustain the needs of her family.

Melina is now requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP to support and improve her business. The loan will be used to pay for two rolls of fish nets, 30 pieces of bamboo, fingerlings and labor expenses. She will also make needed repairs to her fishing boat. She really dreams of improving her business through owning more fish cages so she can make greater profits. With these, she aspires to send her children through college and see them find good jobs.

loans.use: To pay for 2 rolls of fish net, 30 pieces of bamboo, fingerlings, labor expenses and boat repairs

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria V. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 51 years old, married and has five adult children. For over seventeen years Gloria has operated her own multicab service for the local community. She earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Gloria joined HSPFI to gain access to their financial services. Gloria is requesting an initial loan of 5000 PHP that will be used to repair her multicab. Any revenues generated from her business will be used to improve her service.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair her multicab

loans.name: Nerry

texts.en:
Nerry F. is a 51-year-old businesswoman who lives in Tala, Caloocan City.  Her husband, Primitivo, works in a nearby factory.  They have two children, both school-aged.

Nerry works everyday in the comfort of her own home sewing bed sheets and linens.  She counts on regular clients who are very satisfied with her work. She strives to give it her best effort in order to improve the situation of her family.  Nerry earns P25,000.00 net income per month from her sewing business.

She said she started receiving bountiful blessings since she joined the Center for Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006.  Two years ago, she was able to put a computer shop out of her profits from the sewing business.  She is now asking for a loan in the amount of P14,000.00 in order to buy fabrics and other supplies. 

She hopes to open a big boutique so she can hire neighbors and be of help.  She also hopes to hurdle her children’s college education.  



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy fabrics and other sewing supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To renovate her business

loans.name: Jeniva's Group

texts.en:
Jeniva K. is the leader of her lending group in Bushenyi. She is 40 years old and married with 8 children, aged 23 years to 8 months, all of whom are in secondary and primary schools (except one who is still young). She is a business lady involved in the sale of produce in Omukabare Katerera in Bushenyi. Before running this business, she used to sell tea at the road side; she had to change in order to make more earnings.

She has mainly sold her produce to traders from Kampala for 11 years now and she is able to make profits of approximately 150,000 UGX a month, which helps her to pay for her children’s education. She hopes to work hard so that she can own a large amount of stock that she can sell to large markets in Kampala directly. At the moment, Jeniva needs a loan to help buy agricultural produce for resale since part of the profits derived from her business help to pay off laborers. She is indeed a friendly and kind lady and this has won her customers in such a competitive business.

loans.use: Buying agricultural produce for resale.

loans.name: Hach

texts.en: Hach D., 23, is a married mother blessed with two young children. They are not enrolled in school and are dependent on her income. She owns a bigger size of farmland on which she plants many kinds of crops and her husband assists her on the farm. Because Hach D.’s current income is not adequate to pay for her family's daily expenses, she would like a loan from Kiva’s partner HKL for capital to operate a business as a grocery seller in her home. She is hopeful this will provide her with extra income. She proposes to use some of the loan to purchase more farming supplies. Note: Hach D.'s husband appears in the picture.

loans.use: To open a business selling groceries at home

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana P. is getting close to retirement age but never seems to get tired of the things she does every day. She is now 59 years old and all her five children are now grown-ups. She lives with her husband, Gabino, 60, a carpenter. Juliana owns and manages a general store which she started two years ago. She also makes foot rugs weaved from scrap fabric trimmings she gets from neighboring garment factories. She has a small workshop for the foot rugs in her backyard. Juliana also maintains a gaming arcade where kids and kids-at-heart enjoy playing. All these business activities provide Juliana with a sure monthly net income of P10,000. Juliana became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006, the same year when she ventured into making foot rugs and started making money out of scrap fabric. She currently applied for a loan in the amount of P8,000 to buy more scrap fabrics from garment factories which she will use for the production of foot rugs. Juliana is very thankful for having a happy family. She has been dreaming of owning a vehicle they can use to sustain their business. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more scrap fabric trimmings for her foot rug business

loans.name: Norah's Group

texts.en:
N. Norah is the leader of her lending group in Jinja. She is a 39-year-old businesswoman involved in brewing waragi (a distilled spirit) in Mawutu village in Jinja. Before starting out in the brewing business nine years ago, Norah was a housewife. She decided to start her business in order to alleviate her poverty. With a small amount of capital she bought drums and pipes for brewing. Although she is still in business, Norah is faced with the challenge of some of her customers not wanting to pay their bills.

Norah is able to make 100,000/= in weekly profit and this helps to pay her children's school fees and general upkeep expenses. She ensures that she makes quality drinks for her consumers and her dream now is to expand her business further by putting in more capital. She also hopes to build a family house and educate her children to university level. Out of her seven children, one is at university, one is in secondary school, three are in primary school, one is in the nursery section while the last-born is still a baby and not yet in school. Norah is requesting a loan to buy sukaali gulu, a kind of sugar used in the waragi brewing business.

loans.use: To purchase sukaali gulu, a kind of sugar for making waragi

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna G. is from the village of Mahinog, Camiguin. She is 52 years old and married with six school-aged children. To make a living, Myrna owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling art and sign accessories in the local community. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Myrna joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Myrna is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her fourth from HSPFI. Myrna plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nem

texts.en:
Farming a rice crop is the main part of Cambodian people’s daily routine. One of these people, Nem H., 31 years old, is the mother of four children who are dependent on her income. Her first child attends school and also helps her on the farm.

Another main source of income for the family comes from her husband’s commerce. He goes to buy oxen and buffalo at reasonable cost from rural people to resell for a profit.

Nem H. saw that her husband’s business is a profitable one for the family and that is why she requests a loan as capital to allow her husband to purchase many animals for resale. She will use the rest of the loan to grow a rice crop.

Nem H. was not available for the photo, so her husband is shown instead.

loans.use: To enable her husband to purchase animals for resale and to grow a rice crop

loans.name: Sleiman

texts.en:
Sleiman is a 38-year-old single man living with his parents. He has been working as a blacksmith since 2008 to earn income to help satisfy the needs of the family.

Today, Sleiman is requesting to borrow $1,000 to buy tools to better satisfy the needs of his clients.

loans.use: To buy tools for his business

loans.name: Rimaz

texts.en:
Rimaz is a 30-year-old engaged woman living with her parents. In 2007, she decided to open a clothes shop as her own business to help her fiancé to provide better living conditions.

Today, Rimaz is requesting $1,200 to purchase more merchandise to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Betty's Group

texts.en:
N. Betty is the leader of her lending group in Jinja. She is a married woman with four children, three of whom are in secondary school and the last born is a baby. She also helps to take care of two in-laws including paying their school fees and general upkeep.

Betty has owned and managed a fruit and vegetable selling business in Namulesa for four years from which she is able to make 70,000/= of profits a week. She gets her produce from the villages and from her farm because she is a farmer herself and this helps her to have stock all the time and hence more customers.

Betty needs a loan to be able to buy more fruit and vegetables for resale and partly to pay school fees for her children. She is such a friendly and hardworking lady.

loans.use: To buy more fruit and vegetables to sell and to pay school fees

loans.name: Taha

texts.en: Taha is a 46-year-old married man with 2 children. He has owned a phone shop since 2000. Over the years, thanks to his business income, he has been able to meet his children's needs. Today, Taha is requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase more rechargeable cards so he can increase his sales and therefore his income.

loans.use: purchase more rechargeable cards

loans.name: Ngin

texts.en: Ngin T. is an older woman, 60-year-old, and currently lives in Pursat Province. Here she and her husband earn a living by cultivating crops. They own a plot of farmland where they plants rice and they will harvest and collect their productivity when they are mature. This couple was married with 10 children; seven of whom are married and have ready started new homes, while others are single who go to school. Ngin T. will be used her first loan to achieve her goal of having other farmland. She will use this loan to buy a nearby neighbor's farmland on which she will plant crop or rent it out to other farmer for fees.

loans.use: To buy a nearby neighbor's farmland on which she will plant crop or rent it out to other farmer for fees.

loans.name: Tully

texts.en: Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is 19-year-old Tully K. from Mbozi. She is single. Tully has been running a milk-selling business since 2008. She buys milk from farmers on a wholesale basis and sells it retail. She works at the business for twelve hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by two employees. She currently earns about 100 USD from her business. Tully is requesting a loan in order to purchase more milk in bulk to resell. In the future, she plans to continue in the same business. Tully thanks you for your support! About SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more milk in bulk to sell

loans.name: Hanaa

texts.en: Hanaa is a 44-year-old single woman. She has owned a clothes shop since 1999 to provide, along with her sisters for living conditions for the family. Today, Hanaa is applying for a loan of 1,200 to buy additionA. clothes so she can satisfy the heavy demands of the market and help increase her income.

loans.use: buy additional clothes

loans.name: Florence's Group

texts.en: N. Florence is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is 28 years old and married with 2 children aged 12 & 8. Florence is a friendly business lady managing a take away in Kirinya village and she agrees that her main challenge was balancing her own books, but now that she associates with her fellow group members, she is able to manage herself businesswise. She prepares chips, fish and chicken for her customers everyday hence being able to make a profit of 40,000/= out of the business. She vies to expand her business so that she could be able to make more money out of it for paying her children’s school fees, food and clothing. Florence makes the chips out of Irish potatoes and she needs a loan to be able to buy Irish potatoes and chicken for her business.

loans.use: Buying irish potatoes and chicken for making chips and chicken.

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
Hussein is a 46-year-old married man and the father of two children. He has been working as a builder since 1985. With his long experience in the field, he has been able to meet his family needs.

Today, Hussein is requesting $1,200 to buy new tools for his work.

loans.use: To buy new tools for his work

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To open the same business at a new location

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
M. is a 33-year-old single man living with his parents. He has been working as a taxi driver since 1998 to provide, along with his brothers, for living expenses of the family.

Today, M. is requesting $800 to perform maintenance on his taxi to be able to proceed with his work.

loans.use: To perform maintenance on his taxi

loans.name: Loem

texts.en: Loem P., 29, is a married mother blessed with thee minor children who under she cares. She earns a living by working on the farm. A part of family’s expense is contributed by her husband, who sells a piece of wood which used to build a housing hedge. He also goes to the forest to collect or buy a piece of wood and then sells to people who need to build hedge around their house. Loem P. faced a problem after she grown her rice; she lacks some fertilizers to fatten her crop yield. She will be used this loan to purchase fertilizer, as well as she will build a pigpen and then buy piglet to raise for extra income.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, as well as she will build a pigpen and then buy piglet to raise for extra income

loans.name: Annet's Group

texts.en:
For the last seven years, K. Annet has made a living selling dried fish in the Wantoni and Nakawa markets. She is grateful for her success and pleased with how things have gone because she started with one stall and now has two. This new stand has meant more income and more profits. In one market, she now employs a helper to handle sales while she works in the other. She also puts lots of time and effort into make sure that the fish she sells is of high quality. 

Annet has a dream of one day buying enough fish to supply other sellers, and thereby becoming even more prosperous. In the meantime, she has applied for this loan to increase the amount of fish she can sell. Her goal is to increase her income so that she and her husband can take better care of her three children and the one niece they are also raising.

Annet also leads a loan group made up of people who are committed to expand their own small businesses.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Nymph

texts.en:
Nymph C. lives in the village of  Mahinog, Camiguin. She is 37 years old, single and has two school-aged children. She makes a living selling clothes to people in her community. She has been in this business for more than five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from her work.

Last year, Nymph joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and business. She has successfully repaid four previous loans from HSPFI. She used each of them to buy more inventory to sell, and will use this latest loan for the same purpose. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to expand her business

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein 18 years old, single and lives with his parents and five brothers and sisters. He has owned his farming business since 2007, and has applied for this loan for $1,000 to buy the tools he needs to improve his farm's output.

loans.use: to buy tools

loans.name: Bahriddin

texts.en:
Bahriddin rents a little store where he sells construction materials and paints. He buys his goods from different cities wherever they are cheaper and sells them. He purchases goods every week. Bahriddin is married and has two children. He has many constant clients. Bahriddin wants to take a loan for purchasing more goods and have more profit. He wishes to educate his children and hopes that someday they’ll become good persons in society.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. loans.use: To purchase construction materials

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is 41 years old, married and lives with his wife and two children. In 2000, he decided to buy a van and start a business delivering fruits, vegetables and other items to various local markets. Ali has applied for a loan for $1,000 to get his van serviced and buy new tires.

loans.use: to buy new tires for his van, and have it serviced

loans.name: Suzana

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 36 years old Suzana  M. from Mbozi. She is married with 5 children, between the ages of 9 and 20. Suzana has been running a charcoal business since 2007. Client’s business is She sells charcoal, which are small, black pieces of dry earth that are used by many Tanzanians as a fuel to cook their daily meals. Women cook food in small coal pots, in which they arrange mkaa (charcoal), and add either paper, dry grass, old plastic bags or kerosene in order to light them. Because there is such a high demand for charcoal across the country, being a charcoal seller is quite lucrative!
She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Suzana currently earns about 80 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to open the same business at new location. In the future, she plans to improve quality and range of product. Suzana thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To open the same business at new location

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna V. lives in the village of Mahinog, Camiguin. She is 44 years old, married and has five children, all now grown. She makes a living running a sari-sari (or variety) store, where she sells mostly food and other products that customers use daily. 

Last year, Myrna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and business. She has successfully repaid three previous loans from HSPFI, which she used to expand the range of items she sells from her store. She plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to continue to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy new items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Mukaddas

texts.en:
G. Mukaddas is a hard-working married mother of three children. For the past nine years Mukaddas has dedicated herself to selling office supplies. She started her business after her husband's employment with a construction company ended. Without her husband’s income, bills started to pile up so Mukaddas decided to generate her own income to fill the gap. She likes what she sells and has developed a stable enterprise. Now Mukaddas has requested a loan of 5000 TJS to help purchase a new supply of items to sell. This is an important matter for this family's well-being. Please help Mukaddas’s business to grow. She truly appreciates your generosity. More about Tajikistan
Tajikistan, a key post on the Silk Road, is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase office supplies to sell

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 24-year-old single man who lives with his parents. He has been working as a baker since 2005 and has eight years of experience in this field. Today, Mohamad is requesting a loan of $800 USD to renovate the tools in his bakery.

loans.use: To renovate the tools in his bakery

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia O. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin. She is 49 years old and married with five school-aged children. To make a living, Lilia owns and operates a business making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Lilia has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Lilia joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Lilia is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her fifth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase spare parts and a diagnostic device for the repair of electronic appliances.

loans.name: Faridah's Group

texts.en:
B. Faridah is the leader of her lending group in Jinja. She is 30 years old and married with four children aged 14 to 3 years. All her children are in primary school and she would like to educate them until university so that they can become self-reliant.

Faridah owns a restaurant in Ivunamba where, for six years now, she has prepared all kinds of foodstuffs and various kinds of sauce. She is able to make 70,000/= as weekly profits and these, together with her husband’s additions, help to run her home plus pay her children’s school fees.

Faridah has a dream of growing her restaurant into a bigger one so that she will be able to make more profits and employ more people. She needs a loan to be able to buy more foodstuffs for her restaurant’s expansion.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for her restaurant

loans.name: Leny

texts.en:
Leny is the 36-year-old mother of two daughters and is a native of Antipolo City, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is married to Henry who is 31 years old and is an electrician. She is a woman who believes that poverty is not a hindrance to success but a stepping stone for another level of success.

In 2004, Leny joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines. She hoped to have access to capital to start a business with which she planed to help the meager income of her husband. When she received her previous loans, she invested them to start a general store business.

Its already five years since Leny ventured in her general store business and it brings her a good income as it is properly managed. She wants to invest more in this business. Now on her 8th loan, she proposes a loan of 15,000 pesos as additional capital for her business. Specifically, the amount will be used to pay for four sacks of rice, five sacks of charcoal, cases of soft drinks and beverages, groceries, and payment for transportation.

Leny dreams of expanding her business, and being able to own a house and lot. She also aspires to sending her children to school until they finish college and find jobs.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her general store and to pay for transportation

loans.name: Jalal

texts.en: Jalal is a 37-year-old married man living with his child. Twenty years ago he started waxing and painting cars. In 1995, after learning the business he decided to open his own store where he performs paint jobs for cars. Today, Jalal is hoping to borrow $1,000 to purchase merchandise for his shop.

loans.use: purchase merchandise

loans.name: Mukhlisa

texts.en:
For 25 years, Mukhlisa has had a small business which sells women’s underwear. She is married with three children. She is an energetic, enthusiastic entrepreneur who operates her business simply but wisely. An example of this is when she has needed to purchase new clothing inventory. Rather than close her business and travel herself to buy inventory, she has paid other clothing vendors to buy for her so that she can stay and keep her business open. Mukhlisa is asking for a loan to help renew her clothing inventory. The change of seasons means a busy time of year for clothing vendors and this loan will help Mukhlisa purchase a good supply so she can maximize her profits and continue working to develop her business.
