Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a member of the Amani borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa, She is 30 year old woman, she is married.

Fatuma has owned a food business selling local beer for 4 year, she works 15 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 100,000 Tanzanian shillings.


This is Fatuma`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more maize for making local beer.


With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Fatuma hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more maize for local beer

loans.name: Faines

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is 45-year-old Faines M. from Mbeya. She is married with four children between the ages of 18 and 32. Since 2005 Faines has been running a genge business. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, from which the owner sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people send their children to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal, and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

Faines works in her business for 9 to 12 hours per day, 6 days per week, and currently earns about $80 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to buy more rice, sugar, beans and salt in bulk. In the future, she plans to renovate her store. Faines thanks you for your support!

About SELFINA
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania through microleasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more rice, sugar, beans and salt in bulk

loans.name: Rozimery

texts.en:
Rozimery is a member of the Amani borrower group in Kinayanambo, Iringa. she is 24 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 6 and 2 years old.

Rozimery has owned a clothing business selling clothes for 2 years, she works 12 hours a  day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Rozimery`s  first loan from  BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more used clothes for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Rozimery hopes  to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothing for sale

loans.name: Abdul Hadi

texts.en:
The man who is pictured is A. Hadi. He lives in district 8th of Kabul Afghanistan. He is 50 married with 6. He has requested a second cycle individual loan of 50000 Afghani. By the loan he would like to construct his house and buy the essential constructive materials. 
He would like to state that Kiva is a really effective process.

loans.use: purchasing constructive materials

loans.name: Rosta

texts.en:
Rosta is a member of the Amani borrower group in Kinaynambo, Iringa. She is widowed and a mother of 1 child. Her child is 13 yer old.

Rosta has owned a  maize business for 5 years, she works a 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 80,000 Tanzanian shilling.

This is Rosta`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more maize for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Rosta hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more maize for sale

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie T. is from the village of Camanga, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 34 years old, married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Elvie owns and operates a sari-sari or general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste, in the local community. Elvie has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Elvie joined Kiva partner, GDMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elvie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This loan was used to invest in expanding her business. Elvie is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Elaine

texts.en:
“Success cannot be attained without patience and sacrifices,” says Elaine G. for she always believed that patience is the key to success. She is married to Rodrigo and they live in the village of Lawig, Lamut, Ifugao together with their children. The couple works very hard to support the needs of their family.

Elaine manages a general store business while her husband cultivates their little farm by planting a variety of vegetables like tomatoes, beans and eggplant. According to her, she is able to earn a monthly net income of PHP 2,500 from her store which they budget to meet the needs of their family and to support the education of their children.

Elaine wants to improve her business and, in line with this, she would like to borrow PHP 5,000 from Kiva lenders as additional capital and hopes that, through this, her income will also increase.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Mark Lester

texts.en:
Mark Lester is 20 years old and already married to Miracmelie. They are both striving hard to make their marriage successful and have a better life.  They live in Barangay La Paz, Cabatuan, Isabela, a rural and plain area located near the Catholic church and their Barangay Health Center unit. The young couple is blessed with a two-year-old daughter named Haycee Crismacion.

Mark has operated and managed a small bakeshop in front of their house for almost four years. His weekly income of PHP 3,500 is already of big use in the maintenance of his bakeshop. He is now borrowing business capital of PHP 20,000 from Kiva lenders for the continuous growth of his business.

Mark also plans to have a bigger venue where he can hire out-of-school youth in their village. He wishes that he can become a successful entrepreneur someday for the welfare of his family.

Mark is a very hardworking and responsible father, despite his young age. He spends most of his time in making his business grow. He is very thankful that, even at a young age, he is blessed with his own business to provide for the growing needs of his children.

loans.use: To use as additional business capital

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a member of the Amani  borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is 38 year old woman, she  is married and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 14 and 12 years  old.

Rose has owned a fruits business for 10 years, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Rose`s first loan from BRAC-Tanzania, she requested the amount of 250,000 Tsh in order to buy more fruits.


With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Rose hopes to save more money, pay school fess and  expand her business

loans.use: To buy more fruits

loans.name: George's Group

texts.en:
K. George is the leader of his lending group in Ibanda. He is 52 years old and married with six children aged 20 to 6 years, all in secondary school.

George is a hardworking man who manages two businesses: that is, he is a farmer and at the same time has a carpentry workshop in Rwemengo Trading Centre. It’s because of his loyalty that he is successful in business. He does his two businesses interchangeably and employs a few people to help with his businesses so that he can expand his business as well as have a happy and educated family.

George needs a loan to be able to buy farm inputs like fertilizer and quality seeds to ensure quality production.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs like fertiliser and quality seeds

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
“Do not do unto others what you don’t want others to do unto you”. This is the guiding principle of Grace O., a resident of Barangay Lawig, Lamut, Ifugao. She and her husband are already separated and she has a daughter named Dainty Claire. Being a single parent is not easy so she is doing her best to support the needs of her child.

Grace is a retailer, selling different snacks and coconut oil and she also retails cell phone loads through electronic loading. Wanting to further develop her business, she decided to obtain a loan of PHP 5,000 from Kiva lenders as additional capital. This amount will be of great help in maintaining her small enterprise.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: James Mwenda

texts.en: Mr. James M. is 47 years old. He is married to Joyce Mwendwa and is the father of three school-going children. James has a seat-cushion-making business that he has been running for the last nineteen years on a busy street in Narok town. James learned about KADET from a friend who is already a registered client. This will be his first loan which he is planning to use to expand his business by buying more stock to meet his customers’ demands. He hopes to use the profits from the proceeds of this loan to expand his business and employ more people. James’ future dream is that he will be able to build his own house for business and also a residential one for himself and his family. James believes he is hardworking and only needs resources to attain his goal. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more material like leather for seat covers and seat cushions

loans.name: Eugénie

texts.fr: G. Eugénie est née vers 1959 à Sègbohouè à Cotonou. Eugénie est mariée à DEGUENON Emile. Eugénie est mère de  sept enfants, tous scolarisés. Eugénie et sa famille habitent le quartier ZOGBO à Cotonou. Eugénie a été très tôt initiée au petit commerce par sa mère. C'est avec une mesure d'arachide que Eugénie a commencé par faire de la cacahuète. Eugénie a ensuite élargi la vente de cacahuète à d’autres amuse-gueules. Actuellement, Eugénie vend des divers (Bonbons, biscuits, boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, piles, bougies, etc.) et des vivres (farine de manioc, haricot, maïs, huile rouge de noix de palme). Eugénie a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits de la part d’ALIDé. Eugénie a bien remboursé ces prêts.  Eugénie veut augmenter le volume de ses marchandises pour mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle. C’est pourquoi Eugénie sollicite un troisième prêt de la part d’ALIDé.
texts.en:
G. Eugénie was born around 1959 in Sègbohouè in Cotonou. She is married to DEGUENON Emile and is the mother of seven children who are all in school. Eugénie and her family live in the ZOGBO district in Cotonou. She was soon introduced by her mother to working in small-scale commerce. Starting with a measure of peanuts, Eugénie produced the nuts for sale. Then she expanded her sales to include tasty snacks. Currently, she sells various items: candy, cookies, canned foods (milk, sardines, tomatoes), sugar, pasta, soaps for the laundry, dishes, and bath, batteries, candles, etc. and some staple foods (cassava flour, beans, corn, red oil from palm nuts). Eugénie has already benefited from two different loans from ALIDé that she repaid. She wants to increase her volume of merchandise in order to respond better to customer demands. This is why she’s requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of corn, cassava flour, and various other goods

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios and her family live in the rural village of Lawig, Lamut, Ifugao. Her three children are now studying: her eldest is now in college, her second child is in high school, while the youngest is in the elementary level. Despite the economic crisis that they are experiencing, Remedios and her husband continue to strive hard so they can afford to send their children to school and hope that they can have a better future. The couple is really working hard to provide for all the needs of their family.

Farming is the common source of income in their village and her husband is no exception. He plants a variety of vegetables while Remedios is engaged in a vending business. She sells cooked viands (tasty dishes) and snacks in the Lawig National High School and sometimes she also sells fruit and vegetables by roaming around their village.

Remedios is hoping for her business to become progressive and profitable. To do this, she needs additional capital and she is now asking to borrow PHP 5,000 from Kiva lenders that she can use. She hopes that, through her business, she can continue to assist her husband in providing all the needs of their family, especially in sending their children to school.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Constance

texts.fr: Z. Constance est née le 22/10/1978 au Niger, un pays voisin du Bénin. Constance est mariée et mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Constance habite dans la maison de son père à Fifadji un quartier de Cotonou. Constance est allée à l’école mais n’a pas fini le cours primaire. C’est la couture que Constance a fini par apprendre comme métier. Cependant Constance n’a exercé ce métier que pour quelques années. C’est au commerce que Constance s’est finalement donnée. Constance avait vendu de la nourriture devant sa maison. Mais aujourd’hui, c’est des céréales, le maïs en particulier que Constance vend. Constance a eu déjà trois crédits de ALIDé pour ses activités. Constance sollicite ce quatrième prêt pour renforcer son fonds de roulement et accroître son activité de céréales.
texts.en:
Z. Constance was born on October 22, 1978 in Niger, a country neighboring Benin. She is married and the mother of two children who are both in school. She lives in her father’s house in Fifadji, a district of Cotonou. Constance attended school but did not finish primary school. Sewing is what she finally learned as her trade. Yet she worked in this trade for only a few years and finally came to devote all her time to commerce. She used to sell food in front of her house. But today, it’s grains, corn in particular. Constance has already had three different ALIDé business loans. She’s requesting this fourth loan for bolstering her working capital and for growing her business in grains.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy four 100-kg sacks of corn

loans.name: Sara De Lourdes

texts.es:
Sara tiene 59 años de edad y vive junto a su esposo y dos de sus cuatro hijos en el caserío La Zaranda, distrito de Pítipo, ubicado a 45 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Ella se dedica a la apicultura y desde hace 5 años vende los productos que recolecta (miel, polen y propóleo) en la entrada al Santuario Histórico Bosques de Pómac, una área natural protegida por el estado y que es muy visitada por los turistas, también acude a exponer sus productos en diversas ferias de la región.

Posee 20 colmenas (hives or apiaries) en un área de terreno ubicada a media hora del lugar de donde vive y junto a su esposo acude a recolectar los productos con determinada frecuencia, dependiendo del producto, así por ejemplo, recolecta miel de dos a tres veces por año, polen cada tres meses y propóleo cada mes; luego los purifica y envasa en un pequeño taller que tiene en su casa para ofrecerlos a sus clientes los fines de semana, excepto en primavera que vende todos los días, además su producto es solicitado en las ciudades de Chiclayo y Lima.

Sara se encuentra solicitando por primera vez a nuestra Institución un crédito de 1200 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra de envases y etiquetas para poder mantener su negocio durante esta temporada primaveral que es cuando más tiene que vender su mercancía.

Su más grande anhelo es expandir su taller para seguir envasando más productos y dar trabajo a las personas de su localidad, ella es muy querida y respetada por sus vecinos que la consideran una mujer alegre y entregada a su trabajo.
texts.en:
Sara is 59, and she lives with her husband and two of their four children in the Caserió La Zaranda in the Pítipo district, which is located 45 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. She is a beekeeper. For five years she has been selling the products she collects (honey, pollen, and bee glue) in the entrance to the Santuario Histórico Bosques de Pómas, a natural area protected by the state. Many tourists visit the area. She also goes to various regional fairs to show her products. She has 20 beehives (hives or apiaries) on a piece of land that is located a half hour from where she lives with her husband. She goes to collect the products with a particular frequency, depending upon the product. For example, she collects honey two or three times a year, pollen every three months, and bee glue every month. She then purifies the products and puts them in bottles in a small shop that she has in her house. She offers the products to her customers on the week ends. However, in the spring she sells everyday. Her products are sought after in the cities of Chiclayo and Lima. Sara is asking for the first time that our Institution give her a loan for 1,200 PEN. She plans to buy containers and labels to be able to maintain her business during this spring time, which is when she has to sell her merchandise the most. Her biggest desire is to expand her shop in order to keep bottling more products and give work to people in her area. She is very loved and respected by her neighbors, and they consider her to be a happy woman who is devoted to her work.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials to bottle honey, pollen, and bee glue

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
Georgina is married with two children. She sells clothing at a small market in Mukachevo city and has been in this business for eleven years. Being very enthusiastic and optimistic she provides a good example to her neighbors, encouraging them to work more, develop their businesses and deal with any problems.

Georgina would like to borrow 11,000 UAH to purchase more inventory. She would like to have a big variety of items - both expensive and inexpensive items - to attract even more clients.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Chantal

texts.fr: S. Chantal est née le 16 Mars 1975. Chantal est mariée et mère de deux enfants. Chantal est allée à l’école mais, Chantal a abandonné les classes pour apprendre la couture qu’elle n’a pas non plus finie. C’est au commerce que Chantal s’est finalement donnée. Chantal  avait vendu de la nourriture. Aujourd'hui, c’est des épices en poudre (piment rouge, poivre, ail, gingembre, etc.), des oignons et des sacs de charbons de bois que Chantal vend. Chantal dispose également d'un moulin à tomate qu’elle gère. Pour ses activités Chantal a déjà bénéficié d’un prêt d’ALIDé. Prêt qu’elle a bien remboursé. Chantal sollicite ce deuxième prêt pour renforcer son fonds de roulement dans le but de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
S. Chantal was born on March 16, 1975. She is married and the mother of two children. She attended school but dropped out to learn how to sew, which she didn’t complete either. In the end, commerce is what Chantal has devoted all her time to. She used to sell food. Today, it’s powdered spices (red pepper, black pepper, garlic, ginger, etc.), onions, and sacks of charcoal. She also has a grinder for tomatoes that she runs. Chantal’s businesses have already benefited from an ALIDé loan, which she has repaid. She’s requesting this second loan for bolstering her working capital with the goal of further satisfying her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy onions, black pepper, garlic, ginger, chili pepper and charcoal

loans.name: Julienne

texts.fr: D. Julienne est née le 16 juillet 1947 à Cotonou. Julienne est mariée et mère de 6 enfants, tous scolarisés. Julienne est allée à l’école mais n’a pas fini le cours primaire. C’est la couture que Julienne a fini par apprendre comme métier. Cependant Julienne n’a pas exercé ce métier de couture. C’est au commerce que Julienne s’est finalement donnée. Julienne vend divers articles: tissus, huile végétale et autres biens qu’elle distribue à ses clients à crédit. Julienne vend aussi à manger dans une baraque non loin de chez elle. Julienne sollicite l’appui financier de ALIDé pour renforcer son fonds de roulement afin mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
D. Julienne was born on July 16, 1947 in Cotonou. She is married and the mother of six children who are all in school. She attended school but didn’t finish primary school. Sewing is what Julienne finally came to learn as a trade. Yet she has not worked in sewing. Ultimately, commerce is what she has devoted all her time to. She sells various items: cloth, vegetable oil, and other goods, which she distributes to customers on credit. She also sells prepared food in a stall not far from her home. Julienne is requesting financial support from ALIDé for bolstering her working capital, so as to respond better to the demands of her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of rice, 50-liter drums of vegetable oil, and some cloth

loans.name: Harrison Kimani

texts.en:
Harrison is married to Lucy Nyambura and they have two children, Mark, four years old, and Amos, four months.

Harrison has been in the hardware business for nine years. The area in which his store is located is the site of much new development; therefore, he gets lots of customers.

Harrison has had no previous credit history with other MFI's. He was introduced to KADET by existing clients. He is requesting a loan in order to add more stock to his hardware shop, including glass, paint, and building materials. With the extra profit, he intends to build rental houses on his plot.

In the future, Harrison hopes and dreams to open another hardware store. He believes he has what it takes to do this because he is very hardworking.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information about KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add to the retail stock (such as glass, paint, and buiding materials) of his hardware store.

loans.name: Madeleine

texts.fr: K. Madeleine est née en 1980. Madeleine est mariée et mère de trois enfants. Madeleine fut placée très tôt auprès d’une parente qui l'envoya en apprentissage de couture. Madeleine a fini sa formation et reçut son diplôme. Parallèlement à la couture, Madeleine faisait le commerce d'huile rouge, ensuite de tissus. Mais, l’activité principale de Madeleine aujourd'hui est la vente de tissus. En effet, Madeleine vend de façon ambulante ses tissus. Pour augmenter le volume de ses articles, Madeleine sollicite l’appui financier d’ALIDé.
texts.en:
K. Madeleine was born in 1980. She is married and the mother of three children. Very early on, she was placed with a parent who entered her into a sewing apprenticeship. Madeleine finished her training and received her certificate. Along with sewing, she used to have a business selling red palm oil, and then cloth after that. But her main business today involves selling cloth. Essentially, she hawks fabrics. To increase the volume of her goods, she’s requesting financial support from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ten 12-meter bolts of Hitarget cloth

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a member of the Lumwago borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is 30 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 1 child. Her child is 9 years old.

Rose has owned a shop business selling sods, salts,beans, rice for 12 years. She works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 100,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Rose`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 TSh in order to buy more shop commodities for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Rose hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more shop commodities

loans.name: Mary Nyabonyi

texts.en:
Mary is 47 years old and married to A. Obure, an accountant. Together they have two children: Charles, 23, and Phillies, 17.

Mary has operated a clothing sales business for the last three years. She serves mainly middle-class customers who are passersby, as her business is along one of the main roads in town.

Mary has never borrowed from other microfinance institutions before and was introduced to KADET by existing group members. She has applied for a loan, which she plans to use to purchase new lessos (a kind of clothing) for women, which are in high demand in her area. With the extra profits she expects from sales, Mary intends to send her children to the university and to expand her business.

Mary's future hopes and dreams are to become a wholesale supplier of lessos and to venture into the sale of rice within the marketplace.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke.

loans.use: Purchasing new women's lessos (a kind of clothing).

loans.name: Sèlia

texts.fr: Sèlia est une cliente d'ALIDé qui est mariée et est mère de trois enfants. Sèlia n'a jamais été à l'école, ni appris un métier. Très tôt, Sèlia fut initiée au commerce par ses parents. Sèlia vend de pommes fruits et les articles pour bébé : thermos, biberons et autres accessoires de bébé. Depuis, Sèlia n'a pas changé d'activité. Sèlia veut mieux développer son activité. C’est pour cela que Sèlia demande de prêt à ALIDé pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
L. Sèlia is 35 years old. She is married and the mother of three children. She has never been to school nor has she learned a trade. Very early on, she was introduced to commerce by her parents. She sells apples and baby items: thermos, baby bottles, and other accessories for babies. Since then, Sèlia has not changed her business. She wants to develop her business further. To do so, she’s asking for an ALIDé loan to bolster her working capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy apples, thermos, baby bottles, and other baby items

loans.name: Harold

texts.en:
Harold is still single and lives with his parents in the village of Lawig, Lamut, Ifugao.  He helps his parents earn a living while saving something for his future by planting and producing crops.  

Aside from farming, he buys and sells vegetables.  He earns a monthly income of 1,500 Philippine pesos (or about $30 US), which he budgets to use as rolling capital while saving the remainder for his needs.  Harold hopes to increase his income but he needs additional capital.  Thus, he is requesting a loan of 5,00 pesos (or about $125) in order to buy more fruits and vegetables for trading.

loans.use: Additional capital for his crop-trading business.

loans.name: John Kitali

texts.en:
John is 28 years old and is married.  He has two children, Elizabeth and Brian, who are four-month-old twins.

John has been in the general retail business for eight years. His business is located in a densely populated area, and he has many customers.

John was introduced to KADET by a friend in a preexisting group. He has no previous credit history. He has applied for a loan, which he will use to purchase additional stock for his retail shop. He also hopes to complete two rental houses that he had started building in order to boost his income. With the extra profits gained from these investments, John wants to pay school fees for his brothers who currently attend college.

John's future hopes and dreams are to turn his business into a wholesale shop and to own real estate. He believes that, by being a determined and focused hard worker, he will be able to fulfill his dreams.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information about KADET from their website: www.kadet.co.ke.

loans.use: Increasing stock in his retail shop and completing two rental houses he's building.

loans.name: Tulda

texts.en:
Tulda is a member of the Amani borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is 22 year old woman, she is married and a mother 2 children. Her children are 4 and 2 years old.

Tulda has owned a clothing business selling clothes for 4 years, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 80,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Tulda`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000Tsh in order to buy more used clothes for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Tulda hopes to save more money, pay school fess, get more food for family and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes for  sale

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is a 45-year-old mother of five. She braids hair and sells hair extensions. She loves this business because her hair extensions are in high demand and she likes satisfying her customers. Sarah is requesting a loan of 70,000 Nigerian naira (or about $475 US) to purchase more hair extensions to sell. She thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Dally

texts.en:
“Be thrifty; use money wisely." This is one of Dally S.'s life rules. She is from the village of Lawig, Lamut, Ifugao. Due to the difficulties of life, she and her husband, Antonio, try their best to minimize their expenses. This way, they can save for the future of their two children, April Dianne, 13, and Elton Jan, 7. April Dianne is now in her second year of high school, while Elton Jan attends elementary school. Dally and Antonio want their children to become successful, no matter what they choose to do.

Antonio works as an Overseas Filipino Worker, or OFW, in Saudi Arabia, while Dally works as a motorcycle operator. Drivers rent her motorcycle and use it to transport goods. Dally is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to 5,000 Philippine pesos (or about $125 US) to be used for the maintenance of her motorcycle.  She hopes that someday, her family can better their place in life.

loans.use: Motorcycle repairs

loans.name: Idowu

texts.en:
Idowu sells drinks to her retail customers. She has been selling drinks for over ten years. She hopes for a loan in the amount of 100,000 Nigerian naira (NGN) to purchase more crates of drinks to sell.

Idowu is 44 years old and married with three children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell to retail customers.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is a member of the Amani borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is 21 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 1 child. Her child is 4 years old.

Lucy has owned a salon business for 2 years, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 120,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Lucy`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more commodities for salon.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Lucy hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for salon

loans.name: Sussana

texts.en:
Sussana sells foodstuffs like beans, garri, rice, and palm oil. She hopes for a loan in the amount of 140,000 Nigerian naira (NGN) to purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

Sussana is 45 years old and married with four children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Mariana

texts.en:
As a grandmother, Mariana's main priority is her grandchildren, and providing a good life and education for them. Providing for her family is one of the reasons she opened her store when she came to the U.S. 22 years ago. She started selling hair accessories on the street in Upper Manhattan when she came to New York from Ecuador, after having a similar business back in her home country. She is very proud that she was able to open a shop and truly become successful in this country. 

With the profits from her business, Mariana helps her son with his university expenses so that he can become a successful, educated worker. Her son helps her, in return, by working for her as a salesman from time to time. 

Mariana heard about ACCION USA from a friend who recommended she take a loan to develop credit. She will use this loan to purchase back-to-school items, such as backpacks and school supplies, along with fall accessories, that she will sell in her store. She plans to work as hard as possible to expand her business and be able to hire more people in her community. She also hopes to help her son succeed and to help pay for her grandchildren's education, too.

loans.use: Fall accessories and back-to-school gear

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela sells crates of drinks, and she also has a restaurant where she sells cooked foods. She hopes for a loan in the amount of 140,000 Nigerian naira (NGN) to purchase more crates of drinks to sell.

Angela is 42 years old and married with five children. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell.

loans.name: Lelane

texts.en:
Lelane B. is from the city of Dapitan.  She is 41 years old.  Lelane is married and has 5 school-aged children.  To make a living, Lelane owns & operates a business venture in the food sector running a specialized store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks such as bread and noodles in the local community. 

Lelane has been engaged in her business for over 13 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Lelane joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lelane has successfully repaid her previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Lelane is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. 

This will be the 4th loan taken out by Lelane from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 


About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Freeland

texts.en:
Freeland is 26 years old and a resident of Barangay Lawig, Lamut, Ifugao. Through the sacrifices of his parents, he was able to finish his college education. Since he is still single, he is now helping them with their needs and he is also starting to save for his future.

Due to a lack of job opportunity, Freeland ventured into the vending business with a starting capital of PHP3,000.00. He sells cooked meats, rice cakes and frozen foods inside the school campus in their village.

He wants to improve and strengthen his business, but he lacks the business capital. He decided to seek financial assistance from the Kiva lenders a loan amount of PHP5, 000. He hopes that through this, his business will grow. He is positive that he will succeed with his determination and patience in the business.

loans.use: Additional capital for vending business

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a member of the Amani borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is 28 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 1 child. Her child is 4 years old.

Grace has owned a pharmacy business selling medicine for 5 years, she works 12 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Grace`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount  of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more Medicine for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Grace hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more medicine

loans.name: Morifat

texts.en:
Morifat sells crates of drinks, wholesale and retail, to her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for a loan of N140,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell.

Morifat is 42 years old and married with five children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks

loans.name: Tam

texts.en:
Tâm T. Trần was born in 1981 (id: 010117040003). She lives in Xom Cho-Uy No-Dong Anh with her parents-in-law, her husband and two children. Her husband is a taxi driver. Her children are small.

Her family has a store. She sells betrothal gifts and items for rent. She has a monthly income of about 5,000,000 VND. This time she wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to invest in her store.

loans.use: To invest in her store

loans.name: Inspiration Plus Group

texts.fr:
Inspiration Plus est une Banque Communautaire constituée de 32 membres dont Alphonsine est Présidente. Ces membres sont solidairement unis pour un même but, développer leurs activités à travers des crédits reçus de Kiva par l’IMF HOPE RDC.
Alphonsine est vendeuse des poissons, du miel ainsi que des galettes. Elle avait commencé son activité en 2002 avec un capital initial de $50. Après un dur travail et une bonne gestion, elle est parvenue à la faire prospérer grâce aussi aux bénéfices accumulés. Elle compte l'élargir avec le prochain prêt, en y ajoutant des pagnes et autres articles beaucoup recherchés dans son milieu. L'affaire lui génère un bénéfice de $75 par semaine. Alphonsine est âgée de 42 ans, mariée et mère de 3 enfants dont leurs âges varient entre 2 et 4 ans. Un seul est scolarisé.
texts.en:
Inspiration Plus is a Community Bank made up of 32 members whose chairwoman is Alphonsine. These members are united for the same goal to grow their businesses by loans received from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC. Alphonsine sells fish, honey as well as cakes. She began her business in 2002 with an initial capital of $50.00. After hard work and good management, she succeeded in making it thrive thanks to the accumulated profits. She intends to expand it with the next loan by adding pieces of fabrics and other much sought-after items in her environment. The business gives her a profit of $75.00 every week. Alphonsine is 42 years old, married and the mother of 3 children, whose ages vary between 2 and 4 years old. Only one is in school.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To diversify the business by purchasing pieces of fabrics to retail with the intention of increasing profit.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
Aurora is a responsible wife to Marvin and a mother to their two children who are both in the elementary level.  They live in the rural community of Lawig, Lamut, Ifugao.

Her husband works as a contractor in Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya, while Aurora is engaged in selling medicines and groceries in their village.  She wanted her business to become productive and profitable, so she decided to avail herself of a loan of PHP 5,000 from Kiva lenders as additional capital.  She believes that this is a good opportunity for her business to grow.

loans.use: For Additional Capital

loans.name: Bolaji

texts.en: Bolaji Motiatu is 36 years old, married to Bolaji and they have four children. Motiatu sells foodstuffs and she is doing well in her business. Motiatu hopes for the loan amount of N 140,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell.  She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Yen

texts.en: Yen T. D. was born in 1969.  She lives in Xom Cho – Uy No – Dong Anh – Ha Noi with her husband and 2 children. Her husband is a driver. Her son is a university student and her daughter attends secondary school. Yen T. D. sells betrothal gifts for rent. Her monthly income is about 6.000.000 VND.  She has been involved with SEDA for four years. This time, she wants to borrow 6.322.000 VND (or $375 USD) to buy more betrothal gifts for rent.

loans.use: to buy more betrothal gifts for rent

loans.name: Remalyn

texts.en:
Remalyn is 24 years old, single and still living with her parents in the village of Rizal in Santiago City. She raises hogs and sells them after they are three to four months old. She is helping her parents through this small business, which is really a big help in providing for the needs of her family.

In order to maintain her hog business, she is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP from KIVA lenders through Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc. She will use this amount to purchase feed for her hogs. She hopes to sustain and continue developing her business.

loans.use: To buy feed for her hogs

loans.name: Shade

texts.en: Shade sells plastics like bowls, cups, baskets, etc. in her community in Lagos State, Nigeria. Folashade is 45 years old and married with five children. She has been in her business for a long time. She hopes for a loan of 140,000 nairas to purchase more plastics to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more plastics to sell

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a member of the Kinanambo borrower group in Kinyanambo, iringa. She is married and a mother of 3 children. Her children are 20,16,11 years old.

Amina has owned a business selling chicken for 12 years, she works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Amina`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more Chicken for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Amina hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: T buy more chicken for sale

loans.name: Clato Bwonya

texts.en:
Clato is 38 years old and married with four children. His animal farming business is located in Central Likuyani in Eldoret Town. Clato was introduced to KADET by a member. He has applied for a loan which he intends to use to buy a heifer. He hopes and dreams that he may increase his farm animals and also buy land for zero grazing.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients. KADET provides financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is a microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke/.

loans.use: To buy one heifer

loans.name: Anijen

texts.en:
Anijen hails from Antipoly City, Rizal province, in the Philippines. She is 29 years old and married to Deo, who is 31 years old and a jeepney driver. She is the mother of two: a boy and a girl. Given the meager income of her husband, Anijen had to help him, and she looked for a way to make a living. She has small kids to take care of, and it is hard for her to engage in business. She decided to open a sari-sari store (general store).

In 2004, Anijen joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines. She has invested previous loans in her sari-sari store and, with God’s guidance, the business is running smoothly and has been operating for three years already. Now on her fifth loan, she is requesting 10,000 pesos as additional capital for her sari-sari store. The money will be used to pay for assorted goods including groceries and three sacks of rice. She is confident that her business will grow, since her neighbors are regular customers. She dreams of expanding her business and of being able to save money for the future of her kids, so she can send them to school until they finish college and find jobs.

loans.use: To pay for assorted goods including groceries and three sacks of rice

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace sells provisions on a retail basis to customers within her community in Lagos state, Nigeria. She has been in this business for a long time. Grace is 54 years old and married with four children. She hopes for the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma manages her own business. She is 38 years old and married to Jimmy, who is 40 years old and a farmer. She is a mother to eight; six boys and two girls. She lives in Antipolo City, Rizal province in the Philippines.

Farming is the major source of income among Filipinos. Philippines is an agricultural country. Vilma took the opportunity to farm since rice is the staple food for Filipinos and she believes that her farm products will always be sold. In 2008, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, with the intention of having access to loans to finance her farming.

Farming without capital is hard since she needs to supply and invest in the farming inputs, which include labor, fertilizers and pesticides among many others.

Now on her second loan, she proposes a loan of 10,000 pesos to be used to pay for sacks of assorted fertilizer, pesticides, herbicides and labor costs.

She is hopeful that with the support of ASHI, she can put in good farming inputs that would mean sound output or great production. She aspires to send all her children to school and to have a comfortable and durable house.

loans.use: To pay for sacks of assorted fertilizer, pesticides, herbicides and labor costs

loans.name: Rechael Githua

texts.en:
Rechael Githua is 28 years old. She is married and a mother of one child. 

She has a mobile-phone shop that she has been running for the last four years on a busy street in Narok Town.

She learned about KADET from other women who were already registered as clients. This will be her second loan, which she is planning to use to increase her stock of mobile phones, accessories and other electronic goods. With the profits she hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, she plans to open another shop and create employment for other people. She would also like to open up an M-pesa (mobile money transfer) business.

Her future dream is that she will be able to build her own house. Rachael believes that she is hardworking and she only needs the resources to attain her goals.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Buying more mobile phones, phone accessories and other electronic goods

loans.name: Nikki Rose

texts.en:
“Be unique and smart in facing the challenges of life,” says Nikki Rose as she shared her principle in life. She is a hardworking woman who is married to Rolando. They are living in the village of Lawig, Lamut, Ifugao. They are newly married and do not have children yet.

The couple has a strong determination to uplift their status of living through hard work. Her husband works as a tricycle driver while Nikki Rose is engaged in selling cooked viand (tasty dishes) and snacks within their village. She also sells vegetables such as eggplant, beans, okra and bitter melon. 

Having the business is already a big help to their family needs, said Nikki. She also wants the business to grow and for this, she is borrowing PHP5,000 to further maintain growth.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Mitos

texts.en:
Mitos is 40 years old and married to Emeliano, who is also 40. She is a mother to three children; two boys and a girl. She lives in Antipolo City, Rizal province in the Philippines.

Mitos has the talent of sewing. She is known to their village as a good sewer and she receive orders for her sewing services. Sewing is her primary business and she needs capital to sustain its operation. In 2008, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, with hopes of having access to capital. She used her previous loans as rolling and additional capital for her sewing. She has been in the business for almost six years.

Now on her third loan, she seeks 10,000 pesos as additional capital for her sewing business. Specifically, the amount will be used to pay for a sewing machine worth 5,000 pesos and for assorted cloth and threads. She is hopeful that her business will grow and she even dreams of expanding it and to later hire workers. She also aspires to send her children to school until they finish college and to have a more spacious and comfortable house.

loans.use: To pay for a sewing machine worth 5,000 pesos and for assorted cloth and threads

loans.name: Bummi

texts.en:
Bummi produces and sells hair and body cream on a wholesale and retail basis to customers within her community in Lagos state, Nigeria. She started this business seven years ago. She hopes for the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more materials to produce body and hair cream to sell.

Bummi is 47 years old and married with three children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more materials to produce hair and body cream to sell

loans.name: Mien's Group

texts.en:
Miến Thị Nguyễn (id: 010117090023) was born in 1968. She lives in Dai Bi – Uy No – D. Anh with her husband, two children, and her morther-in-law. Her husband is a building worker. Her children are small.

Mrs. Miến raises chickens and sells vegetables in the market and has a monthly income of about 4,000,000 VND. She wants to borrow 5,886,000 VND (approx. 335 USD) to breed pigs and poultry.

Mrs. Miến is the group leader of a seven-member group loan offered by SEDA. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

About the other borrowers in her group:

Huyền Thị Lê (id: 010117090026) was born in 1971 and has four children. She sells fish to restaurants. She wants to borrow 6,758,000 VND (approx. 380 USD) to go to the market.

Đông Thị Phạm (id: 010117090020) was born in 1969 and has two children. She needs 5,886,000 VND (approx. 335 USD) to buy feed for her pigs.

Xuyến Thị Nguyễn (id: 010117090024) was born in 1972 and has two children. She wants to borrow 6,758,000 VND (approx. 380 USD) to buy breeding pigs to sell in the market.

Là Thị Nguyễn (id: 010117090022) was born in 1975 and has two children. She sells gas and spa water. She wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND (approx. 355 USD) to invest in her business.

Mừng Thị Nguyễn (id: 010117090021) was born in 1976 and has three children. She wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND (approx. 355 USD) to invest in her business.

Hương Thị Đồng (id: 010117090027) was born in 1971. She needs 6,758,000 VND (approx. 380 USD) to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To breed pigs and poultry

loans.name: Siloe Plus Group

texts.fr:
Justine L. est présidente du groupe dénommé « Siloe Plus » composé de 25 membres solidairement engagés pour recevoir des crédits de Kiva à travers l’IMF HOPE RDC.
Justine 48 ans, a commencé son activité en 2008. Elle vend de la charcuterie et des gâteaux devant sa parcelle située dans la partie montagneuse à l’ouest de la ville de Kinshasa. Elle est cliente fidèle qui a reçu 5 fois les prêts de l’IMF HOPE RDC et les a remboursés correctement. Le crédit qui lui sera octroyé prochainement lui servira à diversifier son activité en achetant des œufs à revendre en vue d’accroitre le revenu. Actuellement, elle génère un bénéfice de $12 par jour. Elle travaille durement avec une bonne gestion afin d’atteindre son objectif d’ouvrir une boutique dans sa parcelle. Justine est divorcée et mère de 3 enfants âgés de 17 à 25 ans. Deux d’entre eux vont à l’école.
texts.en:
Justine L. chairs Siloe Plus Group composed of 25 members who are jointly liable for loans granted by Kiva through Microfinance Institution HOPE DRC. Justine, aged 48, began her business in 2008. She sells cooked pork meats (such as pâté, "rillettes", ham and sausages) and cakes in front of her plot of land in the mountains west of the city of Kinshasa. She is a regular client who received five loans from Microfinance Institution HOPE DRC and repaid them on schedule. She will use this loan to diversify her business and buy eggs for resale and increase her income. Currently she earns a profit of $12 a day. She is a hard-working lady who manages her business efficiently to fulfill her goal of opening a store on her plot of land. Justine is divorced and the mother of three children aged 17 to 25. Two of them attend school.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy eggs for resale and increase her income

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Noi's Group

texts.en:
Nội Thị Nguyễn was born in 1970. She lives in Dai Bi – Uy No – Dong Anh. She has two children. Her husband is a bodyguard. Her girl is studying in university. She sells soft noodL. soup in the morning (vermicelli and sour crab soup; vermicelli and grilled chopped meat). She has a monthly income of about 5,000,000 Vietnamese dong (about $280). 

She is a group leader of a five-member group loan offered by SEDA. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. This time, she wants to borrow 5,450,000 VND to buy chairs and tables for her restaurant.

About the other borrowers in her group:

Mai Thị Nguyễn was born in 1953. She has two children. She needs 5,886,000 VND to invest in her floriculture (flower farming) business.

Phượng Thị Lê was born in 1970. She has two children. She wants to borrow 5,450,000 VND to invest in her gas shop.

Quang Thị Nguyễn was born in 1959. She has a bazaar. She wants to borrow 5,886,000 VND to buy goods.

Hoa Thị K. Trịnh was born in 1964. She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy food for pigs.

loans.use: To buy chairs and tables for her restaurant

loans.name: Folake

texts.en: Folake is 56 years old and married with four children. She sells underwear. She hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more underwear to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase underwear to sell

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy W. is 57 years old and married. She has three children. She lives in Muguga where she has a dairy farm. She supplies milk to vendors in and around her town and to a dairy plant in the area. She has been in the business for about nine years. 

Nancy has never borrowed from another MFI. This will be her fifth loan with KADET. She intends to use the loan to buy a water pump for her her dairy farm. 

Her future hopes and dreams are to have eight cows in the next three years producing over 80 liters of milk per day. 

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Buying a water pump

loans.name: Zainabkhon

texts.en:
A. Zainabkhon is 49 years old. She and her husband they have three children. To improve her family position and help her husband with family expenses, Zainabkhon started her business 11 years ago. She bakes “lepeshka,” a meat-filled flatbread, at home. Zainabkhon selling most of her products from her home. Zainabkhon does her best to ensure her children with the best future. 

She requests 4800 Somoni to buy flour wholesale, as is  required for her business. Zainabkhon is grateful to all who are supporting her and promises to manage the loan accurately.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy flour wholesale to bake “lepeshka,” the national bread.

loans.name: Oliya

texts.en:
Oliya is 51-year-old widow who lives with her two children. She is a hard-working woman who has always found a way to pay for her family's expenses. Every day, for the whole day, she tends to her general store, and that is how she contributes to her household's economy. Nine years ago, Oliya opened her own general store where she sells all sorts of manufactured products. Oliya works every day to support the education of her children. She is request this loan to increase her merchandise and stock her store, as it was in the beginning, with a variety of products.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need.
