loans.name: Shola

texts.en: Shola is 44 years old. She is single and has two children. Shola sells polyethylene bags of various colors and sizes. The demand for her bags is high and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She is hoping for a loan of N170,000 to purchase more bags to sell. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more polyethylene bags to sell

loans.name: Folake

texts.en: Folake sells fish in the market. She wants to expand her business. She is hoping for a loan of N100,000 to purchase more fish to sell. She is 53 years old and married with 3 children. She hopes to give her children a quality education. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Efe

texts.en: Efe sells baby products, such as baby clothes and creams. She is 33 years old and married with 3 children. She is requesting a loan of N100000 to purchase baby-care products to sell. She thanks all of her Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more baby-care products to sell

loans.name: John Alikula

texts.en:
John Alikula is 47 years old and is married to Pasiliza Muhonja. John burns and sells charcoal. He has had this business for a while. His business is located in Eldoret.

John was introduced to KADET by a group member. He has applied for a loan to expand his charcoal business. With the extra profit, he plans to diversify into selling poultry and potatoes. John also has a garden. He plans to use part of the loan to prepare his garden for the next planting season. In the future, he wants to expand his farming business.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Buying trees to burn into charcoal

loans.name: 29 Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
"Hương N. Thị (192) is a 39-year-old woman who lives in the town of Thanh Hoá. Hương is the leader of a 6-member loan group that is sponsored by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 29 (029 - Nam Ngạn).

Hương is married and has 2 school-aged children. To making a living, Hương makes and sells a variety of food products in the local community. Hương has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2008, Hương joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hương has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1963500 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. She is now requesting a new loan of 6000000 VND which will be used to expand her business. This will be Hương's third loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Hương plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1. P. Thị T.nh (193) is a 30 year-old woman who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her specialized retail store.

2. N. Thị Tuyết  (191) is a 52 year-old woman who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her specialized retail store.

3. C. Thị Duyên (190) is a 45 year-old woman who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her food stall.

4. M. Thị Phượng (189) is a 38 year-old woman who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food.

5. N. Thị Sáu (258) is a 45 year-old woman who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her general store.

* Mrs. Thinh does not appear in the picture because she was in the hospital giving birth to her youngest child. 





About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.




*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.




Hương N. Thị (192) là 39 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá. Hương là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 29 (029 - Nam Ngạn).




Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán các loại thực phẩm khác nhau trong cộng đồng địa phương. Hương thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 10 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Hương kiếm được khoảng 4000000 VND. Vào 2008, Hương đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Hương đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 1,963,500 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,000,000 VND.




Khoản vay sẽ là 3rd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.




Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:




1. P. Thị T.nh (193) là 30 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.




2. N. Thị Tuyết  (191) là 52 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.




3. C. Thị Duyên (190) là 45 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.




4. M. Thị Phượng (189) là 38 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.




5. N. Thị Sáu (258) là 45 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa.




Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.




*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: David Mutisya

texts.en:
David is 41 years old and is married to Patriciah. They have three children, Mary, who is 14-years old; Leonard, who is 10 years old, and Annah, who is five years old.

David has run a retail shop for five years. He has no previous credit history from other MFI's. He was introduced to KADET by members of an existing group.

David's business is located in densely populated area with middle-class customers who rely on his shop because it is the only one near their homes.

He has applied for a loan to increase his stock of cereals, such as rice, beans, and, maize, which are in demand, but which is needs funds to purchase. With the extra profits from his business, David plans to build rental houses.

His future hopes and dreams include turning the business into a wholesale businessand become a wholesale distributor. David believes he is focused and hardworking.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy cereals for his food store

loans.name: Raphael Ndirangu

texts.en:
Raphael Ndirangu is a 28-year-old single man. He owns a retail shop. He has been a retail trader for five years. He has been making a good profit, so he wants to venture into transportation business by buying a motorbike.

He has never borrowed from another MFI and was introduced to KADET by a friend. He has applied for a loan to use, along with the profit from his store, to buy a motorbike for his new transportation business.

His future hopes are to expand his business and own a wholesale store.  

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Leonara Penina

texts.en:
Leonara is 28 years old. She is married to Martin Moya, who works in a clearing and forwarding company. They have three children, Hellen, Rose and Wayne, who are 12, 6-1/2 and 2 years old, respectively.

Leonara was introduced to KADET by existing group members. She has no previous loans from other MFIs. She has been in the clothing materials business for three years. Her business is in a densely populated with reliable monthly customers.

Leonara will use her loan to buy more material for women's dresses. The demand for this material is high, especially at the end of each month, when the business is at its peak. Leonara plans to purchase a sewing machine with the extra profits from her loan.

Her hopes and dreams are to be a wholesaler and own a material shop. Leonara believes she is hardworking and focused enough to accomplish this goal.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To Increase her stock of ladies' dress materials during the peak season

loans.name: Catherin Group

texts.en:
The Catherin Group is a group of five entrepreneurs led by Catherin S.. Catherin is 33 years old. She dropped out of school in seventh grade due to poverty. She is married and has three children. She also cares for a sibling, Her children range in age from 8 to 18 years old and their educational levels are 1st through 8th grade. She lives in a commercial community called Waterside that is south of downtown Monrovia, Liberia.

Catherin sells underwear. She buys wholesale and sells retail to customers of Waterside Market. She started her business 16 years ago with a very small stock, but her store has improved bit by bit. Catherin believes that talking nicely to customers makes them want to come back and buy from you; that’s her secret for maintaining customers.

Catherin needs this loan to purchase more underwear at wholesale prices so she can earn more profit to meet her family's needs, especially educating her children. Her goal is to expand her business to a very high level. She dreams that she and her family can become successful.

loans.use: To buy underwear to sell

loans.name: Tchotcho

texts.fr: Cette dame assure seule l’éducation scolaire de ses 02 enfants. Elle habite le quartier de Bè-Souza à Lomé. En 2000, elle s’est lancée dans le commerce de sacs de maïs, parce qu’elle était débordée par les besoins de sa famille. Cette activité lui a donc permis, non seulement de se prendre en charge, mais aussi de subvenir aux besoins de sa progéniture. Elle a loué un entrepôt de vente de maïs  qui lui réussit bien ces temps-ci. Elle arrive à maîtriser peu à peu les rouages de ce commerce ; mais elle a un besoin criant de renouveler son stock, c’est pourquoi elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES. Elle est persuadée que ce prêt apportera un changement positif dans son commerce.
texts.en:
This lady by herself ensures that her two children are educated.  She lives in the Bè-Souza district in Lomé.  In 2000, she started doing commerce in sacks of corn because she was overwhelmed by family needs.  Her business enables her not only to support herself but also to provide for her offspring.  She has leased a warehouse for selling corn, and this has been very successful for her recently.  She's managing to master all the fine points of this business;  but she has a glaring need to renew her inventory;  this is why she's requesting a WAGES loan.  She is convinced this loan will bring a positive change to her commerce. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of corn

loans.name: Abiodun

texts.en: Abiodun sells jewelry, such as wristwatches, earrings, and bracelets. Abiodun is 30 years and married with 2 children. She is hoping for a loan of N50,000 to purchase jewelry to sell. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more jewelry to sell

loans.name: Amos

texts.en: Amos is 70 years old and married. He has 20 children. Amos sells groundnut oil. He has been in the business since 1999. He is hoping for a loan of N100, 000 to purchase more groundnut oil to sell. He says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groundnut oil to sell

loans.name: Koami

texts.fr: Ce jeune homme a appris le métier d’informatique ; il n’est pas marié et n’a aucun enfant à sa charge. Malheureusement pour lui, il n’a jamais pu trouver un emploi pour mettre ses compétences au service d’une institution donnée. C’est pour cette raison qu’il a décidé l’année dernière de se lancer dans l’activité de maraîchage dans le quartier de Dabarakondji à Lomé. Pour ce faire, il a recruté un jeune homme qui maîtrise les cultures. Actuellement il approvisionne les vendeuses de feuilles de salades et de  toute sorte de légumes au Grand Marché de Lomé. C’est pour acheter de nouveaux intrants (les graines) qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES. Il compte sur sa meilleure connaissance du marché pour rembourser le crédit dans les délais exigés.
texts.en:
This is a young many who learned computer programing as a trade. He is not married and has no children at all to support. Unfortunately for him, he was never able to find employment for putting his skills to work in a given institution. For this reason, he decided last year to embark on a market-gardening business in the Dabarakondji district in Lomé. To do so, he recruited a young man who supervises the crops. Currently, he supplies retailers with salad greens and all sorts of vegetables at the Grand Market of Lomé. To buy new supplies (seeds), he's requesting a WAGES loan. He's counting on his better knowledge of the market to repay the loan per the required due dates.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies (seeds)

loans.name: Jabbor

texts.en:
B. Jabbor is 59 years old. He is married and has 4 children. Jabbor's goals are to grow in his personal life and in his business. His wish is to offer better service to his customers. His dream is that God continues to provide him with more life to get ahead and to fulfill his goals. 

Jabbor is a taxi driver who travels through the streets of Kanibadam, Tajikistan in search of customers. He has owned his business for 3 years. Currently Jabbor’s car needs some repairs, so he wants to borrow 4500 Somoni. He will use the loan to buy spare parts for his car. Jabbor thanks Kiva and all lenders who make this help possible.     
       

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy spare parts to fix his taxi

loans.name: Daniel Plus Group

texts.fr:
Daniel Plus est un groupe des micro-entrepreneurs dont Espérance est dirigeante. Ces membres sont solidairement unis pour recevoir des prêts de Kiva dans le but de développer leurs activités. 

Espérance T. est une femme déterminée à mener sa vie dans les affaires. Elle vend des pagnes ainsi que de la boisson. Elle est entrée dans le monde de micro-entreprise depuis 1994. Espérance a déjà obtenu trois fois les crédits de l’IMF HOPE RDC et les a remboursés totalement. Elle envisage renforcer le stock de ses marchandises au moyen du prochain prêt. Elle achètera des pagnes et de la boisson. Actuellement, son activité génère hebdomadairement un bénéfice de $30. Son ambition est de gagner plus de bénéfice en achetant directement des produits à l’étranger. Espérance est âgée de 39 ans, mariée et mère de 5 enfants âgés de 2 à 16 ans dont quatre fréquentent l’école.
texts.en:
Daniel Plus is a group of owners of small businesses chaired by Espérance. Its members are jointly liable for loans granted by Kiva to grow their businesses.

Espérance T. is determined to be a successful businesswoman. She sells pagnes (lengths of brightly colored African print cloth) as well as drinks. She became a microentrepreneur in 1994. Espérance received already three loans from Microfinance Institution HOPE DRC and fully repaid them. She intends to use this loan to expand her inventory. She will buy pagnes and drinks. Currently she earns a profit of $30 a week. She will seek to make more profit by importing her products herself.

Espérance is 39 years old, married and the mother of five children aged 2 to 16. Four of them attend school.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pagnes and drinks and expand her inventory

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Ngozi

texts.en: Ngozi is 27 years old. She is married and has two children. She sells sarongs and clothes of various colors and sizes. She is hoping for a loan of N140,000 to purchase more sarongs and clothes to sell. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and clothes to sell

loans.name: Massan

texts.fr: Cette femme a appris le métier de coiffure ; son mari est directeur d’une école privée. Le couple a un enfant à sa charge. C’est en 2007 que son mari l’a aidé à ouvrir son atelier de coiffure dans le quartier d’Adakpamé à Lomé. Elle a pu fidéliser bon nombre de clientes grâce au travail bien fait qu’elle fournit. Il arrive même que certaines clientes parcourent de longues distances pour venir soigner leurs cheveux chez elle. Elle a besoin d’acheter certains produits cosmétiques et produits de soins en ce moment, c’est pour cela qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES. Ce prêt lui permettra également d’apporter certaines modifications de structure dans son salon de coiffure.
texts.en:
This is a woman who learned hairdressing as a trade.  Her husband is the director of a private school.  This couple has one child to support.  In 2007, her husband helped her to open a hair salon in the Adakpamé district in Lomé.  She was able to earn the loyalty of a good number of customers, thanks to the good work she does.  It so happens that some customers come from afar to have their hair done by her.  She needs to buy certain cosmetic products and hair care products at this time.  To do so, she's requesting a WAGES loan.  This loan will also enable her to reorganize her hair salon.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cosmetics and hair care products

loans.name: Hidoyat

texts.en:
K. Hidoyat is 51 years old. She is married and she uses all the money she makes to care for her children and grandchildren. Hidoyat has 8 years of experience preparing and selling dried apricots. She always makes very productive use of her capital, adding inventory to her supply in a way that allows her to meet her customers' needs. She is also very polite and considerate, and her clients are always very happy with the service they receive from her. 

Because her business is doing so well, she is increasing her net worth month by month. Today, Hidoyat is requesting 3000 Somoni to purchase dried apricots. She will use the loan to process the apricots in order increase the range of goods that she sells. Hidoyat expresses her gratitude for everyone who is supporting her and promises to repay her loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: To buy dried apricots

loans.name: Akinola

texts.en: Akinola is 38 years old and married with 2 children. He sells cocoa beans. He has been in the business for the past 5 years. He is hoping for a loan of N50,000 to purchase more cocoa beans to sell. He say "thank you" to all Kiva lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more cocoa beans to sell

loans.name: Malika

texts.en:
S. Malika is a dynamic and ambitious 47-year-old woman. She is married and has 3 children. For 3 years, she has had a small business processing dried apricots. Thanks to the quality of her products and the experience, she grown in this sphere of business. She has earned a solid reputation among her customers and the demand for her goods has grown, allowing Malika to contribute significantly to her household. 

Now, Malika is requesting $700 USD to buy dried apricots so she can process and resell them. Malika hopes that she will continue to provide her children with education so they will be able to get an adequate education. She expresses her gratitude to everyone who is supporting her.

loans.use: To buy dried apricots to sell

loans.name: Akouvi Victoire

texts.fr: Cette femme s’est spécialisée dans la vente d’huile dans le marché d’Akodessewa à lomé. Elle a débuté ce commerce depuis 1991 pour pouvoir apporter sa contribution financière à son mari menuisier pour l’éducation de leurs 02 enfants. Elle s’approvisionne le plus souvent à Agbodrafo, ville située à quelques kilomètres de Lomé. Elle dispose de beaucoup de clients fidèles, à cause de la bonne qualité de ses huiles, faites à partir de la noix de coco. Certaines revendeuses viennent aussi s’approvisionner auprès d’elle en bidons d’huile. Elle a un besoin urgent de s’approvisionner en bidons d’huile, c’est pour cette raison qu’elle voudrait avoir un prêt de WAGES pour acheter 50 bidons d’huile.
texts.en:
This is a woman who is specialized in selling oil at the Akodessewa marketplace in Lomé.  She started this business in 1991 to be able to do her financial share to help her husband, a carpenter, to educate their two children.  She usually stocks up in Agbodrafo, a city located a few kilometers from  Lomé.  She has many loyal customers because of the good quality of her oils, which are made from coconuts. Also, some retailers come to her to supply themselves with drums of oil. She has an urgent need to stock up with drums of oil.  This is the reason she would like to obtain a WAGES loan, so as to buy 50 of them.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy containers of oil

loans.name: Zeinab

texts.en:
Zeinab is a 37-year-old woman who lives in southern Lebanon. Zeinab has been selling accessories for four years. She sells perfumes, beauty products, make up, hair accessories, and much more. She is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua to purchase merchandise and buy a shelf for her shop. This is her third loan and she has always repaid on time. 

Zeinab is special in her work because of her location. Her clients are her friends, neighbors and people from her region. When she first started her business, she had difficulty finding the proper place to open her shop. Zeinab decided to start her business because she had sales experience. Because before she opened her shop, she used to sell from her house. In the future, she plans to improve her shop.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and buy a shelf for her shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase his livestock by purchasing a dairy cow.

loans.name: Jimoh

texts.en: Jimoh is 32 years old, married, and has 2 children. He sells motor parts and has been in business since 1996. He lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State. He hopes for a loan in the amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more motor parts to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders

loans.use: To purchase more motor parts to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase his livestock by purchasing a dairy cow.

loans.name: Shola

texts.en: Shola is 35 years old, married, and has 4 children. He sells sarongs. He hopes for a loan in the amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 40-year-old man who lives in southern Lebanon with his wife and their four children. Ali has been working as a mason for the past ten years. He is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work and to pay his children’s school tuition. This is the first time that Badih has requested a loan. 
Ali is special in his work because he does it well. His clients are people from his region. When he first started his business, he didn’t have much experience. It wasn’t easy for him to develop networking. In addition, he had to learn the new technique in order to face his competition. Ali decided to do his business because he wanted to have independent work. In the future, he plans to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his work and to pay school tuition.

loans.name: Adeola

texts.en: Adeola sells jewelry like earrings, necklaces and bangles. She is also a hair stylist and she sells hair extensions and creams in her shop. She hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more jewelry to sell. Adeola is 42 years old and married with two children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase jewelry to sell

loans.name: Essam

texts.en:
Essam is a 35-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. Essam has owned a laundry for four years. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he had financial issues. He decided to set up his business because he learned this trade when he was young.

Essam has requested a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase an iron press and aspirator for his work. This is his third loan cycle and he has always paid on time. Essam's previous loans helped him to improve his laundry. In the future, he plans on further improvements.

loans.use: To purchase an iron press and aspirator

loans.name: Muritalu

texts.en: Muritalu is 34 years old and married with 2 children. He sells medicine and he has been in business for the past 2 years. He hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more medicine to sell. He say thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine to sell

loans.name: Wessam

texts.en:
Wessam is 31 years old and lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. He has owned a gym since 2004. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When Wessam first started his business, he had difficulty purchasing all the necessary machines. He decided to set up the business because his father used to be a trainer and he learned about the business from him.

Wessam has requested a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase a running machine for his gym. This is his third loan cycle and he has always paid on time. His previous loans helped him improve his gym by purchasing new machines. In the future, he plans on further improvements.

loans.use: To purchase a running machine for his gym

loans.name: Bostonoy

texts.en: Bostonoy is a very diligent mother with big plans for her business. For the past seven years she has been dedicated to the buying and selling of manufactured products. She carries out this work with the support of her elder sons and it's generating an important economic source for her, allowing her to provide for the well-being and education of her younger children, who are the reason and motivation to keep working hard. Bostonoy, seeing a great demand for her business, wants to increase her stock and for this reason is requesting the loan. With your support, she hopes she will be able to improve her financial situation even more. loans.use: To purchase manufactured products for increasing her range of goods

loans.name: Mhammad

texts.en:
Mhammad is a 40-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. He has been working as a car repairer for twenty years and also sells used spare parts.

Mhammad requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase spare parts for his work and to pay for his children school tuition. This is his third loan and he has always paid on time.

Mhammad’s previous loans helped him improve his work. His clients are his friends and neighbors, as well as traders. He decided on doing his business because he learned it since he was young and when he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties.  In the future, he plans on improving his store.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for his work and to pay for his children school tuition

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia is 68 years old and married with 8 children. She sells cooked foods. She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more food stuffs to cook and sell. She say thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more food stuffs

loans.name: Mavluda

texts.en: Mavluda is 50 years old and lives with her children in her own apartment. For more than two years she has been selling manufactured products. She is a very orderly and well-organized person and keeps a detailed record with all the data of her clients to be able to offer them her products and attend to them properly. In the future she would like to have a commercial stand where she can exhibit her products. This is Mavluda’s first loan with IMON International and she feels obliged to work with commitment and wholeheartedly with the members of her solidarity group. The total amount requested will be spent on buying manufactured products in bulk. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her store

loans.name: Oisara

texts.en: N. Oisara is a married woman with three children. She started her business as the result of economic pressure since her husband's salary was not enough to meet their family expenses. She began to investigate what work she could do. About thirteen years ago, one of her friends recommended she sell clothing and she decided she'd try that business. Little by little she brought in more clients which increased her income, since her commissions increased as she sold more clothing. Oisara is applying for a loan of 3,000 Somoni to buy merchandise and to fill existing client orders. She hopes that you will collaborate with her. Together with her family, she thanks you for supporting them and helping the family move ahead. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To use as additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Kodjo

texts.fr: Monsieur Kodjo n’est pas menuisier, mais il s’est spécialisé dans la vente de meubles, à savoir des fauteuils, des armoires, des lits, des tables et autres accessoires. Ce commerce lui permet d’assurer parfaitement tous les besoins essentiels de sa femme et de ses 07 enfants. Il reçoit tellement de demandes de ses clients, qu’il est obligé de se rendre plus d’une fois au Ghana, le pays voisin, dans le mois pour s’approvisionner. Tous ses meubles sont faits en tecks, qui est un bois de qualité supérieure dans la confection de ces objets. Il a débuté ce commerce en 2001  et son étalage se situe dans le quartier d’Anfamé à Lomé. C’est pour lancer une nouvelle commande qu’il sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour répondre aux attentes de ses clients. Il n’a aucune inquiétude pour rembourser son prêt.
texts.en:
Kodjo is not a carpenter but he has specialised his business into a furniture business, especially armchairs, armoirs, beds, tables and accessories. His business lets him provide for all of the essential needs of his wife and their 7 children. He receives so many requests from his clients that he is forced to go to Ghana more once per month to restock his supplies. All of his funiture is made of teak, a superior quality wood typically used in furniture manufacturing. He started his business in 2001 and his store is located in the Anfame quarter in the city of Lome. He has requested a loan from Wages (Kiva Field Partner) to purchase a new order, and so that he could meet his clients' demands. He is very confident about being able to repay his loan.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase household furnishings.

loans.name: Elohor

texts.en: Elohor is 32 years old and married with 2 children. She lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She has a salon where she makes lovely hair styles for her customers and she also sells hair extensions. She is requesting for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more hair extensions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase alcoholic drinks.

loans.name: Precious Group

texts.en:
Doris is twenty-three years old. She is single and has no child. She lives alone in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town.

Doris is a trader, trading in cosmetics, and she is the leader of a trust bank group called Precious. The group members are engaged either in farming and/or trading activities. They sell or supply in their local market and nearby communities and sometimes trek to nearby community markets to sell. They want a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To buy stock for her business

loans.name: Brandina

texts.en:
Bradina is a member of the Amani south in Kinayanambo, Iringa. She is 32 year old woman, she is married.

Bradina has owned a soap business for 5 years, she works 12 hours a day and  she earns a monthly profit approximately 80,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Bradina`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more soap for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of that loan,Bradina hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more soap for sale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 48 years old and married with 6 children. She sells provisions like milk, noodles, toothpaste, detergent, etc. She opens her shop daily from 7am-7pm. She is a hard-working woman. She is requesting the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell.

loans.name: Edo

texts.fr: Cette femme s’est spécialisée dans la vente de produits congelés, que ce soit la viande de dindons ou de poulets. Elle est seule actuellement à élever ses 02 enfants. Elle a débuté ce commerce en 2004 dans le quartier d’Akodessewa à Lomé. Elle a loué une boutique de vente de produits congelés ; et ce commerce lui permet de payer les frais de location de sa boutique et de subvenir à tous les besoins de sa famille. Elle a ouvert sa boutique sur une route très fréquentée, ce qui fait qu’elle réalise de bonnes affaires. Elle reçoit même des demandes lors de certaines fêtes dans le quartier ; beaucoup de personnes l’apprécient beaucoup parce que ses viandes ne sont pas avariées. Elle a besoin en ce moment de renouveler son stock ; c’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 25 cartons de viande de poulets et 25 cartons de viandes dindons. Elle est convaincue qu’elle remboursera son crédit à temps.
texts.en:
Edo specializes in selling frozen food products, such as turket and chicken meats. She is a single mother of 2 children. She started out in 2004 in the district of Akodessewa in the city of Lome. She rents a frozen food store, and this business allows her to cover the store rent costs and to provide for all of the needs of the family. She set up her store in a well-travelled road, which is why she sees good business. She even receives orders for certain holidays in the district. Many people look to her because her meat are of good quality. She is currently in need to restock her supply, which is the reason why she is requesting a loan from Wages (Kiva Field Partner). She will purchase 25 boxes of chicken meat and 25 boxes of turkey meat. She is determined to pay off the loan on time.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase frozen food products.

loans.name: Ganiru

texts.en: Ganiru is 44 years old and married with 4 children. He sells tyres and has been in the business for a long time. He hopes for the amount of N50,000 to purchase more tyres to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more tyres to sell

loans.name: Komi

texts.fr: Ce monsieur est un mécanicien qui s’est spécialisé dans la peinture auto. Il est marié et a 03 enfants à sa charge. Il est devenu le meilleur spécialiste dans la peinture d’automobile, car il a débuté cette activité depuis 1994. C’est donc un vétéran qui a ouvert son atelier dans le quartier d’Ablogamé à Lomé. Il a beaucoup de clients fidèles qui aiment et approuvent tous ses services bien faits ; il dispose aussi beaucoup d’apprentis mécaniciens car bon nombre de parents veulent voir leurs enfants devenir comme ce monsieur. Actuellement il a besoin d’acheter un nouvel appareil de pulvérisation de la peinture ; c’est pour cela qu’il sollicite un crédit de WAGES. Le prêt servira également à agrandir et améliorer son atelier de mécanique générale. Il est fier de ses prestations et n’a aucun souci pour honorer ses engagements.
texts.en:
Komi is a mechanic who specializes in autobody work. He is married and he is the father of 3 children, still in his care. He has become the best autobody specialist because he has been in this occupation since 1994. Therefore as an experienced veteran in the field he opened his shop, located in the district of Ablogame in the city of Lome. He has many loyal customers that appreciate the work well-done. He also has a number of apprenticeships, given that many parents want their children to become like him. He currently requires a new painting tool, which is why he is requesting a loan from Wages (Kiva Field Partner). The loan will also be used to expand and improve his general auto mechanic workshop. He is very proud of his services and he has no concern over honoring his commitments.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a tool to paint cars.

loans.name: Edoh Kossi Laurent

texts.fr: Ce jeune homme a ouvert une baraque de vente de cartes de recharges servant également lieu de cabine téléphonique. Il a débuté ce commerce depuis 2007 à Lomé et cette activité lui permet de subvenir à ses propres besoins. Il s’est abonné auprès des deux prestataires de téléphonie mobile à Lomé, à savoir Togocel et Moov, ce qui lui permet de bénéficier de beaucoup de réduction. Des revendeuses ambulantes de ces cartes viennent s’approvisionner chez lui, ce qui lui permet de réaliser de bonnes affaires. Pour lancer une nouvelle commande, il sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter en nombre considérable des cartes de recharges Togocel et Moov. Il est célibataire et sans enfant.
texts.en:
This young man has opened a stand selling rechargeable phone cards and providing a telephone booth. He began this work in 2007 in Lomé, and the business allows him to support himself. He has accounts with two cell phone providers in Lomé, Togocel and Moov, which allows him a good reduction in cost. Young women who sell his cards walking to and fro in the streets come to buy them from him, and that brings in a tidy profit. In order to put in a new order, he is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy a considerable number of recharge cards for Togocel and Moov. He is single and has no children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of charge cards for cell phones

loans.name: Yinka

texts.en: Yinka is 40 years old and married with 2 children. She has a salon where she styles hair for her customers and she also sells hair extensions within her community in Warri, Delta State. She is requesting the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more hair extensions. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Ananita

texts.en: Although she has only one child, who is now of adult age, Mrs. Ananita H. strives hard to provide for her small family. At 52 years old, married, and a resident of Sebucao Diutay, Barangay. Sebucao, San Enrique, Negros Occidental, Ananita is not only working for the present needs of her family by helping supplement the income of her husband, she is also making plans for her old age. Four years ago, Ananita started a general store which provides a steady income for her family. In addition, she also started raising pigs in her backyard and she used the profits from the pig raising to capitalize on a third business venture - direct selling of a networking product. From these three business activities, she earns an average amount of PHP 6,000 per month, which is enough to cover the college expenses of her only child, and the balance she plowed back into her business. She manages her cash flow well and was able to pay off her last loan of PHP 12,000 without missing a payment. Now, for her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ananita is borrowing another PHP 12,000 so that she can continue expanding the operations of her three business activities. She is very thankful that she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon because it has made a big difference in her family's quality of life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To use for business expansion

loans.name: Abi

texts.fr: Mme Abi est mère de 02 enfants, et est mariée. Elle a appris le métier de couture ; en 2002, elle a ouvert sa boutique de couture dans le quartier d’Ablogamé à Lomé. Cette activité lui permet d’apporter sa contribution financière dans la vie du foyer. Elle a appris la haute couture, activité qu’elle exerce dans la perfection, ce qui lui permet de fidéliser sa clientèle. Elle dispose aussi des apprentis couturières qui l’aident dans sa tâche. Actuellement elle est débordée dans sa tâche, c’est pourquoi elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter une nouvelle machine à coudre Janôme, afin de pouvoir répondre à temps aux commandes de ses clientes.
texts.en:
Mrs. Abi is the mother of 2 children and she is married. She learned to be a seamstress and in 2002 she opened up a sewing workshop in the Ablogamé neighborhood in Lomé. This business allows her to contribute to supporting her family. She learned 'haute couture', which she is very good at, and that keeps her clients coming back. She also has apprentice seamstresses who help her. Presently, she is overwhelmed with work so she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy a new sewing machine (Janôme brand) so that she can get customers' orders ready on time.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of a sewing machine

loans.name: Dependable God Group

texts.en: Margaret is fifty-two years old. She is divorced and has given birth to three children, all of whom are in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. Margaret is a trader. She trades in pastries. She is the leader of a trust bank group called Dependable God. The group members are engaged in farming and/or trading activities. They sell to and supply their local market and nearby communities. They sometimes trek to nearby community markets. They want a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Folashade

texts.en: Folashade is 35 years old and married with 3 children. She sells electronics. She hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more electronics to sell. She say thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more electronics to sell

loans.name: Phebe

texts.en: Phebe is 45 years old and married with 3 children. She sells crates of eggs in wholesale and retail to her customers. The demand for her crates of eggs is high and she hopes to meet the demand of her customers. She hopes for the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more crates of eggs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of eggs to sell

loans.name: Yvonne Andréa Akouvi

texts.fr: Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenus le commerce d’alimentation générale ; elle exerce cette activité depuis 2001 dans son domicile dans le quartier de Bè-kpota à Lomé. Cette activité lui permet d’aider son mari à subvenir aux besoins scolaires de leurs 02 enfants. Actuellement elle a fait une étude de son marché et elle a noté qu’elle pourra aussi se lancer dans le commerce pagnes et de bijoux. C’est pour cela qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 25 pagnes de qualité Wax Hollandais, 20 pagnes Hitarget, 15 pagnes Soso, mais aussi des bijoux de bonne marque. Elle compte sur son expérience et sur la demande de ses clients pour faire fructifier ce prêt.
texts.en:
This woman sells groceries to earn a living. She has been in this business since 2001, in her house in the Bè-kpota district in Lomé. This business allows her to help her husband pay the school fees for their two children. Presently, she has studied her market and feels that she can go into selling African "waxcloth" and costume jewelry as well. For that reason she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 25 lengths of "waxcloth" (Hollandais brand), 20 lengths (Hitarget brand), and 15 lengths of Soso brand, as well as some good quality costume jewelry. She is counting on her experience and the demand of her clientele to make this loan pay off.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of "waxcloth" and costume jewelry for resale

loans.name: The Blood Of Jesus Group

texts.en: Dorothy is thirty-nine years old. She is married and has given birth to two children, both of whom are in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. Dorothy is a baker. She is the leader of a trust bank group called The Blood of Jesus. The group members are engaged in farming and/or trading activities. They sell to and supply their local market and nearby communities. They sometimes trek to nearby community markets. They want a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah M. is 27 years old, married and has been blessed with two daughters. Sarah runs a business selling old and new sacks in Sega market, Mombasa. She has been in this business for the last four years. The family also owns a matatu for passenger service that plies the Mshomoroni-kengeleni route, which supplements their daily income.

She was introduced to KADET by another client in a different group and she has applied for her first loan. She plans to purchase more sacks for sale with the money.

Sarah hopes to become a leader in the sack business in Mombasa city.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Purchasing an assortment of sacks for both retail and wholesale trade.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary is 46 years old and married with 6 children. She sells crates of drinks. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for the loan amount of N 140,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell.

loans.name: Oluwatoyin

texts.en: Oluwatoyin is 52 years old and married with 4 children. She sells fairly used clothes. She hopes for the amount of N 100,000 to purchase more clothes to sell.  She say thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothes to sell

loans.name: Akossiwa Marguérita

texts.fr: Cette femme est une vendeuse ambulante de bijoux dans le quartier d’Adakpamé à Lomé ; elle a débuté cette activité depuis 2003. Ce commerce lui permet d’aider financièrement son mari tailleur à subvenir aux besoins de leurs 02 enfants. Elle vend ses bijoux dans les institutions aussi bien privées que publiques. Elle dispose de beaucoup de clientes qui la sollicitent beaucoup. Elle se rend le plus souvent au Bénin, le pays voisin pour s’approvisionner ; actuellement elle n’a plus presque de stock, c’est pourquoi elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour lancer des commandes de nouveaux bijoux.
texts.en:
Akossiwas is a travelling sales woman selling jewelry in the Adakpame district of the city of Lome. She has been running this business since 2003. Her business permits her to help her husban, a tailor, provide for the needs of their 2 children. She sells to private and public run businesses. She has a large client base, who patronize her frequently. She goes to Benin as often as she can, the neighboring country, to replenish her inventory. She is sold out of her inventory and this is why she is requesting a loan fro Wages (Kiva Field Partner). She wants to start a new campaign selling the new jewelry.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase jewelry

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Mrs. Helen A. lives in the village of Brgy. Cambaog, in the town of Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She is 43 years old and married with 4 children - the oldest is 23 and the youngest is 14 years old. Her main goal in life is to help her husband raise their family well while striving hard to move them out of poverty.

Before she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon, she thought that this was an impossible dream because how could she expect people to lend her money when she could not offer any collateral as a security for the loan? But she did not lose hope in looking for ways to earn a stable income so that she could send her children to school and sustain the daily needs of her young family. This is why Mrs. A. sought to become a member of  NWTF-Project Dungganon when she heard that she could borrow money without any collateral because it was the MFI's objective to empower poor women so that they could have a better future for themselves and their family. 

She used her first loan to set up a rice retailing business and now 8 years later it continues to provide well for her family.  She profits about PHP 5,000 which she uses to pay the school expenses of her kids, support the needs of the household, and sometimes there is even enough to cover minor house repairs. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000 was her 12th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. She used it to invest in a new business venture - raising livestock - and it was a good run; she was able to pay her installments on time and was able to pay off the whole loan without any delay.

Now for her 13th loan cycle, Helen is again borrowing PHP 19,000 which she will invest in her general store and livestock raising business ventures as additional working capital, and she intends to use the income she gains from this to pay for the tuition fees of her children.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy and sell rice

loans.name: Michael Gichuki

texts.en: Michael is 34 years old and married to Esther who is a businesswoman. They have one child who is five years old. Michael was introduced to KADET by existing group members. He has no loan from other micro-finance institutions. He has been in the vehicle maintenance and auto spares business for six years. His customers are business people dealing with auto parts and public service vehicle owners who purchase parts for their vehicles. Michael has applied for a loan which he will use to import new and second hand spare parts. With the extra profits, he intends to expand his business fully, stop selling secondhand parts and rely solely on new parts. Michael believes he is hardworking, determined, and focused and thus wants to accomplish his future hopes and dreams which includes starting a business selling motor vehicles. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To import new and used auto spare parts from Uganda

loans.name: Bisiola

texts.en: Bisiola is 35 years old and married with a child. She sells medicine and provision. She hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more medicine and provision to sell. She say thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine and provisions.

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en:
Christiana is 55 years old and married with five children. She is determined to lift her family above poverty. She lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She sells crates of drinks wholesale to her customers and has been in this business for long.

Christiana hopes for the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell.

loans.name: Nyame Sun Sum Group

texts.en:
Christiana is 44 years old. She is married and has given birth to a child who is currently in school. She lives with her husband and child in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town.

Christiana is a baker. She is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Nyame sun sum’, meaning God’s spirit. The group members are engaged either in farming and/or trading activities. They sell and supply in their local market and nearby communities. They sometimes trek to nearby community markets to sell. The group members want a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To buy stock in bulk.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is 50 years old and married with three children. She owns a shop where she sells medicines to her customers within her community in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria.

Helen is requesting for loan of N140,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Jonalyn

texts.en: Mrs. Jonalyn O. is 32 years old and lives in the village of Sitio Serena Enclaro, in the town of Binalbagan, Negros Occidental. She is married to Diosdado O. who, because of a lack of employment opportunities in their town, is presently employed as a security guard in Manila, leaving her to fend for their five young children who range in age from the oldest who is just 8 years old to the youngest who is just a week old. Finding herself in a situation where she is a single-parent of five very young children, and the wife of an OFW (Overseas Filipino Worker), albeit without the perks of a dollar remittance, she was forced to think of ways to support her family because the money her husband sends home is just not enough for the needs of the family. At first, Jonalyn started helping in her mother's candy-making business, and distributing the finished products to various general stores in her community and in the neighboring towns. As she proved to be a good businesswoman, her mother handed the reins of the candy business to her. Gaining confidence from her success in the candy business, Jonalyn started looking for other business opportunities within her area of expertise and she thought - why not try baked goods? But Jonalyn did not have enough capital to start a bakery business, so when she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon, in 2007, this was the business venture she wrote in her business proposal for her first loan. And even with just a very small loan, she was able to buy materials and equipment to start operations. Now, two years later, she is happy because she is now able to provide employment to eight people in her neighborhood whom she hired to help her in her bakery. Her success has not stopped Jonalyn from looking for more income sources - she also does direct-selling of beauty products in her community, and these activities earns about PHP 22,000 per month - enough to support her family, pay for her loan, and have enough left for savings for the future needs of her children. Her last loan of PHP 20,000 was fully paid on time, and without any delays. Now on her 9th loan, Jonalyn wants to borrow PHP 23,000 so that she can infuse additional capital into her bakery and other business ventures. She plans to use the income to invest back into the business while setting aside some money for the education of her young children. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Peace

texts.en:
Peace is 46 years old and married with three children. She sells drinks to make a living. She is happy with her business because she has lots of customers that patronize her business and she hopes to expand this business.

Peace is requesting the loan of N140,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Happiness

texts.en:
Happiness is the mother of four children. She is a petty trader who sells foodstuffs like garri (a granular flour made from cassava roots), rice, beans, pepper, Maggi (seasonings) and others. For the past 10 years, she has been in this business. She resides in Lagos State, Nigeria, and is 30 years old.

Happiness has been with LAPO Micro-finance for three years and is requesting the loan amount of N160,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and expand her business. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders and LAPO Micro-finance for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs

loans.name: Wycliffe

texts.en:
Wycliffe is a married man and the father of one child. He has been in the motorcycle business in Naivasha town for the last five years. 

He was introduced to KADET by his friend, who is also a client of KADET. This will be his second loan with the organization. He is planning to buy another motorbike and will employ someone else to operate it for him. 

He believes that buying another motorbike will increase his income flow.

His future plan is to buy his own taxi, which he will operate in Naivasha town.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Buying another motorbike

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria is married with four children. She is 31 years old. She sells provisions and foodstuffs in her shop. She hopes for the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more provisions and foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson is married to Esther Nyokabi, and they have a five-year-old son who is going to school. Wilson has been selling second-hand clothes and shoes in Naivasha for the last five years.

He heard about KADET through a friend and joined. He has applied for his first loan with which he is planning to buy more second-hand clothes and shoes to boost his stock. In the future Wilson plans to expand his business by not only selling second-hand clothing but new clothes as well.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET at: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more second-hand clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a refrigerator for her busness

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en:
Elijah is 29 years old and married to Caroline Mueni. He has been in the auto repair business for the last eight years in Naivasha. He was told about KADET by his friend. This will be Elijah’s first loan. He is planning to buy a welding machine for use in the garage.

Currently Elijah is employed by a local mechanic, but in the future he plans to open his own auto repair business.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET at: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buying a welding machine.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase of sacks of maize

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy palm nuts to produce palm oil

loans.name: Awo

texts.fr: Cette dame a ouvert dans le quartier de Dabadakondji à Lomé un restaurant de vente de riz parfumé, de pâte de maïs et de sauce de gombo, de mouton et de poulet. Elle exerce cette activité depuis 2000 ; pour vite répondre à temps à la demande de ses clients, elle a recruté des jeunes filles pour assurer un bon service. Aux heures de pause, elle reçoit beaucoup de clients à la fois de l’administration publique que du secteur privé. Pour renouveler son stock, elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 02 sacs de maïs, 10 sacs  de riz, 05 bidons d’huile et divers condiments pour la cuisine. Elle est mariée et mère d’un enfant. Elle compte sur la fidélité de ses clients pour vite rembourser son crédit.
texts.en:
This lady has opened a restaurant in the Dabadakondji neighborhood in Lomé, selling scented rice, maize porridge, and stews with okra, mutton, and chicken. She has been in this business since 2000; in order to be able to serve her customers appropriately, she has hired some young women to wait on customers. During break-times, she gets a lot of customers both from public administration and from the private sector. In order to replenish her stocks, she is asking for a loan from WAGES to buy 2 sacks of rice, 5 jerrycans of oil, and various condiments for her dishes. She is married and the mother of one child. She counts on her customers' repeat visits to reimburse her loan rapidly.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of sacks of maize, rice, jerrycans of oil and condiments

loans.name: Ann

texts.en: Ann is a married mother of two children who are both in school. She has been selling her wares for the last two years in Naivasha town. Ann was introduced to KADET by a friend. This will be her second loan, which she plans to use to buy more basins and boost her stock. In the future, Ann wants to own her own store from which she can operate her business of selling general wares.

loans.use: To buy more basins to sell

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is a married 30-year-old woman with four children. She sells planks at a wood market in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She has been in this business for the past five years, and hopes that her loan of N140,000 will allow her to purchase more planks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more planks to sell

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice is a 43-year-old married woman with six children. She sells drinks, provisions and clothes. She hopes that her loan for N50,000 will help her buy more of these things to sell. She thanks you for the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, drinks and clothes

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elise S. is a 34-year-old dedicated mother who aims to help her husband support their family and provide for the future of her two young children, ages one and five years old. She hopes that by providing them with a better education, they will be able to help her and her husband in their old age. 

Elsie and her family live in Hacienda San Jose Baling, Libacao, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. Her husband buys and sells livestock in neighboring towns. Elsie became engaged in food vending to supplement her husband's income. Grilled food is popular among Filipinos, and Negros in particular is famous for its barbecue chicken. Hence, Elsie decided to offer her clients a wide variety of grilled and barbecued food served hot off the grill. Elsie bought charcoal in bulk for her food business, and now also sells that to her neighbors to make extra money. 

For two years, Elsie has enjoyed tending to her food business and helping her husband support their family. Her business earns an extra PHP6,000 per month. Elsie conscientiously divides her income, setting aside a certain amount for her children's future and to budget for her family's needs. She invests the rest of her money back into her business, and is a good money manager. She paid off her last loan, taken out for PHP15,000, with no problems. 

Now on her seventh loan, Elsie wants to borrow PHP16,000 so that she can purchase livestock, which she intends to raise and sell in the future. The income from this venture will again be saved for her children's education and to make repairs to her house. In this photo, Elsie is posing near her food business with a display of barbecued chicken parts, hot dogs and bread on a stick.

loans.use: To purchase livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is a 39-year-old married woman with four children. She sells all types of medicines and has been in the medicine business for the past 12 years. She hopes to receive a loan for N150,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. She thanks you for the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Antoinette

texts.en:
Antoinette I. is 35 years old, is married with four children aged between 15 and 2 years, and she has three dependents. She lives in Kigali, the capital of Rwanda.

Antoinette has owned a small shop for three years where she sells different kinds of merchandises as shown in the photo. She opens her shop everyday from 7:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.

Before requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company, Antoinette was not able to earn more profit to help her to get more food for her children and to satisfy all the needs of her family.

With this new loan she hopes to earn more profit so that she is able to provide more food for her family and pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica sells provisions. She is 36 years old and married with three children. She is from Edo State, Nigeria. She is requesting the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase provisions and foodstuffs to sell. She thanks you for the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and foodstuffs

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is 47 years old and married with six children. She sells drinks and tailoring materials to make a living. She is requesting the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more drinks and tailoring materials to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Edwine

texts.en:
Edwine O. is 24 years old and married to Mwajuma. They have one school-going child. He has been in the auto-repair business for the last five years in Naivasha town.

He was introduced to KADET by a friend and this will be his first loan with the organization. He is planning to buy a buffing machine for use in the garage as he has noticed that this is a service that can give him a competitive edge.

In the future, Edwin wants to open up his own garage since he is currently employed.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Buying a buffing machine

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Mrs. Letecia L. is a 57-year-old resident of Pader, Barangay Aguisan, which is a part of Himamaylan City in the Negros Occidental region. She is married to Hilario, who is a construction worker, and blessed with three adult children. Letecia is also an active member of her church council, is the chairwoman of the community outreach committee, and teaches catechism in school. Even while she keeps busy with her community work, Letecia still manages her many businesses very well despite her age. She continues working because it makes her happy to earn a daily income.

Letecia aimed to help her husband when she opened a general store using her first loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. She noticed that the store provided a steady income if she just stocked it well with goods popular with her customers. To this end she invested in a refrigerator so that she could sell cold food and drinks.

Letecia did not stop looking for other business opportunities. This led her to invest in a food vending business selling fried chicken in her community. She also started a retail business in rice with her most recent loan. Because of her wise investments and her skillful business acumen, she is able to pay her loan installments on time and in full within the period she has promised. With her excellent credit record with NWTF-Project Dungganon, Letecia is being granted higher loans.

Now that two of her children are gainfully employed, the L. family’s quality of life is finally on the rise. With her eighteenth loan, Letecia is proposing to use 29,000 PHP to invest in her general store and rice retailing business. She plans to use her profits to continue to expand her business operations while helping to support her family.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through its alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a dollar a day to achieving realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live lives that they can finally call honorable ones. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To invest in her store & her rice business

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 34 years old and married with four children. She sells cooked foods and drinks. She also sells shoes made by her husband that give her additional income.

Evelyn is requesting a loan of 90,000 NGN to buy food and drinks to sell. She thanks you in advance for the loan.

loans.use: To buy more food and drinks to sell

loans.name: Okeremute

texts.en:
Okeremute is 29 years old and married with three children. To make a living, she sells VCDs (video CDs).

Through the Lift Above Poverty Organization she hopes to obtain a loan of 140,000 NGN to purchase more VCDs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more VCDs to sell

loans.name: Irene

texts.en: Irene W. is 35 years old, married to Joseph Mukinya, and they have one school-going child. Irene has been selling basins in Naivasha town for the last two years. Irene was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be the second loan she will be servicing with KADET. She is planning to buy more basins to add to the stock of her retail business. In future, Irene plans to move from the open-air market to a sheltered place so that weather and climate change won’t affect her sales. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more basins to sell

loans.name: Lovelyn

texts.en: Lovelyn sells provisions and drinks of all brands. She is 32 years-old and married with four children. She is from Edo State, Nigeria. She is asking for a loan of NGN 120,000 in order to purchase more drinks and provisions to sell. She thanks you for the loan.

loans.use: To purchase provisions and drinks

loans.name: Juan Jose

texts.es:
Juan trabaja como costurero como dependiente, por las noches trabaja como independiente para poder incrementar sus ingresos, es su principal fuente de ingreso con lo que cubre su manutención vive en la casa de sus padres ubicado en la zona de Pasankeri de la ciudad de La Paz.
 
El crédito lo destinará para comprar una maquina de coser para poder facilitar el trabajo que tiene cono costurero de chamarras.
 
Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada permite aprobarle el préstamo solicitado por Juan.
texts.en:
Juan works as a tailor as an employee but at night he works for himself to increase his income. His extra earnings are his primary source of funds to cover household expenses. He lives in his parents' house located in the Pasankeri zone in the city of La Paz. He will use the loan to buy a sewing machine to use in his work in sewing jackets. This is his first loan with Impro whose evaluation process has approved the loan requested by Juan.

Translated from Spanish by Kristina Howe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a sewing machine to sew jackets

loans.name: Fatila

texts.en: A. is 47 years-old and married with four children. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells kerosene and grand pepper and tomatoes. She has been in this business for eight years.
